description:
Delicious Vietnamese fare, everything tastes superb here!

A group of us came here for our dear friend Joseph's birthday party.  The owners are a husband and wife team aka dynamic duo (Chris & Tina), who graciously hosted us with what felt like a 10-course dinner family style.  Food coma indeed!  We literally shut the place down.  From the scrumptious crab to the fresh spring rolls, nobody leaves hungry.  I'd like to suggest bibs please j/k.  The savory dishes make me want to come back for more.  The owners plan on retiring, so if you've always wanted to come try Aux Delices, now is right the time.  

They have an extensive wine list, and if you're not into wines, there's beer and sake to choose from.  For non-alcoholic beverages, you can't go wrong with Vietnamese coffee.  Parking is difficult in this area...if there's a will, there's a way.  

'Til we meet again ~ cheers and see you on Yelp (SYOY)!
author: Christine R.

description: Not bad! Got the banh xeo- crispy with a good amount of stuffing on the inside. The asparagus crab soup was good but tiny for the price! And they put way too much sesame oil on top. The small bowl of pho was comically small. Overall- not bad, would come back!
author: Vivian D.

description: It's a nice clean restaurant. Pho was so-so. Food was mediocre. Thai tea was pretty good, but will not be going back.
author: Lorenzo H.

description: There were great aromas when we walked in the door!! Garlic noodles were the best and spring rolls!! Great service too!!
author: Hazel M.

description:
Delicious authentic Vietnamese food! The environment of this place is nice and cozy, perfect for a date or gathering with friends. 

The banh xeo (Vietnamese crepe) was HUGE! Perfectly crispy with tons of meat and other fillings. This is much better than the banh xeo my mom makes haha. Came with a ton of lettuce to wrap in and yummy fish sauce for dipping. The noodles with imperial rolls were great! Definitely would recommend either ordering that dish and maybe even imperial rolls for the table as well bc those were delicious. Bo luc lac (filet mignon cubes) is one of my favorite dishes of all time and this one did not disappoint. 

Definitely a great spot for Vietnamese food with reasonable prices and very friendly service!!!
author: Courtney N.

description: Authentic Vietnamese food with nice service. The spring rolls were crispy and flavorful and the papaya salad tasted so fresh with shrimp!
author: Tammy L.

description:
Super great food. Picked up some
Soup for my wife while she was sick and now I'm hooked on the place!
author: Daniel W.

description:
This is an amazing Viet restaurant in the Bay Area..highly recommend it! 
Love their foods and service
author: Joe D.

description:
I came here on a Friday with a bunch of friends at around 8:30pm. We had 12 people and were separated into 2 tables, one near the front and one in the back. 

I was not particularly wowed by the food. I think the prices are a bit high for the quality/ amount of food you get. The service was pretty good but it was on the slow side. 

For some reason, I thought I'd judge a Vietnamese restaurant by its quality of pho broth and it was a mistake. I received a tiny bowl of noodles with lukewarm soup that lacked any kind of pho flavor. Yeah, so don't order a pho here. I do not think it is what they are known for....

My friends ordered rice/ noodle combination platers, which I'd say are your best bet here. I'd also say order their Imperial Rolls because they were delicious. 

Overall, I'd give this place another try when I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Alice L.

description: Wonderful food. We get the garlic noodles, vegetables and shaking beef. Incredible dishes. They deliver and are wonderful people too. True family restaurant.
author: scott o.

description:
This is one of my favorite Vietnamese restaurants. They have many interesting dishes that you don't see on the menu at a simple Pho place.

Their caramel clay pot dishes are delicious. I also love their flat rice noodles with ground pork.
author: David T.

description:
Ordered via Grub Hub and it took two hours for my food to get delivered.  I didn't mind because there is heavy traffic by my place during traffic hour and i did feel bad for the delivery guy.  

The two orders of garlic noodles, garlic shrimp & crab was amazing! The crab was saucy and finger licking good, perfectly complemented the garlic noodles.  It looked like i spent hours in the kitchen!  Thank you Grub Hub & Aux Delices!
author: Melanie N.

description: Took my white friend here to try out some viet food. The service was painfully slow and the pho was watered down. Should have know better than to order pho on Polk! I should have just stuck to the San Jose area for some viet grub.
author: Connie M.

description: We had the most amazing meal tonight. The Banh Xeo crepe appetizer was just the right crispness and combination of flavors that made it so unique and so memorable. The Bo Luc Lac was the most amazing filet mignon stir fry we've ever had. The bite sized morsels of meat were tender and cooked to perfection and the carmelized onion was a beautiful finishing touch. The Grilled Basa fish combined with rice noodles, vegetables and peanuts was such a refreshing way to eat fish, we savored every bite. And the salt and pepper prawns were amazing. Our comments over and over again was that was such a good meal. You are our favorite Vietnamese restaurant by far!
author: Rick S.

description: First glance looking in the window this looks like a very fancy old school Vietnamese Restaurant...guess what, it is!  It has a comfortable feel, reminds me of places I used to frequent with my parents as a kid, super clean, perfect amount of lightening, a quiet vibe to it, and just the right amount of Vietnamese flare.  The staff is extremely attentive and usually it's open enough for immediate seating.  I was in the mood for some Pho and it did not disappoint.  Grabbed a large serving of the Chicken Pho and it was well more than I needed but first I ordered the Imperial Rolls!  This is a MUST, their imperial rolls are incredible with all the fixings such as lettuce, mint, and parsley to wrap them in..simply perfect.  In fact I just might make a meal of the Imperial Rolls next time.  I added a side of brown rice for good measure and my meal was complete.  Such a great price for everything as well.  Great place to go for some great Vietnamese comfort food, great portions, great price, in a great atmosphere.
author: Wolfgang M.

description: The best pho to kick a cold! Try the house made hot sauce for an extra kick. I've gone here for 12 years and the service and quality is always excellent.
author: Sara M.

description: I can see why it's probably good but I ordered delivery to my hotel and it was the driest meat in the pho with chicken (btw I didn't order chicken so it was super annoying). The pork and shrimp spring rolls are also disappointing because the pork is like jerky where it shouldn't be and last I called and asked for siracha and they sent me one packet. Anyway for delivery they could be better at the above.
author: R. C.

description: The lemongrass tofu vermicelli is fantastic. Love this place. Only thing they need is a Ford GoBike station nearby so I can bike there and eat there more often!
author: Patrick T.

description:
Wonderful, friendly service here.
We are vegetarians, always a challenge due to diet restrictions, but they modify dishes for you according to your diet.
Delicious food with friendly service.
author: Vidhi V.

description: Some restaurants come and go but this place has been consistently great for the 10+ years that we've been going. All of the dishes in the clay pot are incredible, and the glass noodles are also a favorite. We usually get it delivered but the atmosphere at the restaurant is super cozy too. A real neighborhood favorite, year in and year out.
author: George P.

description: Great food, relaxed environment, one of our favorite neighborhood spots. Clay Pot Salmon Curry and Beef Noodle Pho are the go-to's.
author: Evan M.

description: Delicious food served by very nice people who take pride in serving delicious, memorable dishes.
author: Fiona M.

description: Food was Americanized vietnamese food but still kept the authentic vietnamese taste which I really enjoyed. The staff was nice.
author: Trang N.

description:
This isn't your typical Pho spot. I found myself craving a bowl of Pho while in Russian Hill, Yelped this little spot right up. Let me tell you, I can see myself becoming a regular here. The location of this restaurant is incredibly convenient, there aren't any other Pho spots near Russian Hill. When I say this isn't your typical Pho spot, I mean it in regards to the atmosphere and service. Unlike other Pho restaurants, Aux Delices has an elegant interior with an intimate appeal. 

Food:
Banh Xeo
Vietnamese crepe. Crispy pan fried crepe filled with prawns, pork, bean sprouts and onions   13.00

Pho Tai Hay Ga
Beef or chicken boodle. Slices of rare beef or chicken with rice noodles in a traditional beef broth  10.00
+added meatballs to chicken boodle for an extra 2.00

We tried the Banh Xeo which is basically a fried crepe with prawns inside, it's an interesting concept and it was super tasty! I would definitely order again. We also got the Pho bowl, which is the main reason why I visited this place. I got the beef and the boyfriend got the chicken flavor. They were both pretty legit Pho bowls. The dishes were all well portioned, typically 2-3 bucks more than an average Pho restaurant, but it's worth it. 

Service:
Incredible service. Both the waiters and bussers were very attentive and friendly. My water glass was never empty, which I always appreciate.   

Atmosphere:
The interior is more on the fancier side, but still maintains that casual vibe. You get the atmosphere of a romantic restaurant but without the pressure of dressing up or getting too formal. I think that's why I liked this place so much, you can get a bowl of Pho but still have that intimate dinner experience.
author: Stefany Z.

description:
We came here for a team celebration dinner and it was easily a favorite!  There were 8 of us, so we ordered family style and shared, so we could sample many of their dishes.  Everything was well cooked, with distinct seasonings and presented beautifully.  

As a family business, you can tell the personally touch and passion behind the cooking. 

We thoroughly enjoyed our meal and everyone left with happy tummies and a lovely evening of team bonding. You can't ask for more than that.
author: Linh L.

description: This place is decent but parking is tough. Food is reasonably priced and restaurant is nice for a Vietnamese restaurant.
author: Byron L.

description: This is the best Vietnamese restaurant in SF. The cha ca here is delicious so close to the one from Hanoi (might be even better). Highly recommend it.
author: Matt T.

description:
Started off with the summer rolls, imperial rolls and papaya salad. All super delicious, although the salad wasn't spicy as the name suggests. Then we ordered the sautéed shrimp, fried tofu with vegetables and cha ca. I really enjoyed the cha ca here. However, it might be an acquired taste. The tofu and shrimp dishes were also good. I think I could have found something better on the menu though. 

Ended the meal with fried bananas and ice cream. I didn't care for the bananas but I could use more ice cream! Lol 

Lemonade could use more sugar. That's what makes it so good at other viet restaurants! Hahah

The restaurant is nice & cozy and able to provide pretty good service-- definitely better than what I'm used to from Vietnamese restaurants.
author: Phi N.

description:
It's a ripoff for what you get in terms of portions and flavor. All of the meats looked and tasted very low quality and most of the dishes were lacking in preparation.

Charbroiled pork slices appetizer - it didn't even come rolled.. Came with 3 pieces of lettuce, a scoop of vermicelli, and some rubbery pork. That taste wasn't bad, but it's DIY, and not the fun kind.

Claypot pork and prawns - DO NOT GET. The pork was too thick and dry. The prawns were tiny. The sauce was too sweet and salty, and not the right consistency. And not worth it. I could've made it myself much better for half the price.

The Vietnamese dumplings (banh cuon) was ok. The rice shell was a bit too thick. It didn't come with the vegetables that it usually should come with. 

Flank steak skewers - good flavor, but dry beef and texture wasn't great.
author: Ai N.

description:
Again one of those places i wanted to try. Came here for lunch with the brother. 

When we came in, this place was almost empty, only couple other customers...we came in at the time when it was getting close to closing time for the lunch time before dinner hours. There was only one waitress waiting in the front who deal with the customers during the lunch hours and she was all in the back when we walked in

Give us the lunch menu when got to the table. Has lesser selection for lunch. We wanted the ca kho (caramelized fish) but wasnt on the menu. It was until we ask the worker if they have it which they actually do...so then she gave us a different menu which has more option of food to choose from(probably it could for dinner). When looking at their menu, it has a variety of vietnamese authentic food to pick other than Pho. Most of their food are comfort food that i eat at home so its not the usual food you see from most vietnamese restaurant

Things i ordered:

Ca kho(caramalize fish): it was good and very flavorful but its very saucy that its better to eat with rice. You can eat the sauce and rice itself too. When the waitress first brought this dish to my table, my brother and i thought it look kind of burnt because of the dark color it had. I smelled the burntness too. But when you eat it, it actually doesnt have that burnt taste. 

Had the beef skewers(#43). Comes with 2 sticks of the beef and has some vegetables in the middle, peanut, fish sauce to dip your meat, and couple slices of oragne. The meat had good amount of marination that you dont really need to dip any sauce

Had the crab, egg, asparagus soup. Very yummy. Plenty of flavor. Has enough salty and peppery flavor.

I like how each of the dish that we got came out hot. Not sure since there wouldnt many customers at the time we went

All the foods that my brother and i were good but i thought it was a little expensive for a vietnamese restaurant. The portion of the food of each plate that we got were more like for 2 people so it wouldnt be good for large group. If you go with large group and get the food that we got, you may need to get double in order for everyone to have more than enough. Unless you get all of dishes, thats no problem.

Its different if you get the noodle soup or rice plate since you can eat that on your own since it meant for one person

After i left this place, not sure what they put in the sauce, but i had some dryness to my mouth. 

Even though it was only one person working and it wasnt pack, each dish came out at a reasonable time. I enjoy the food here. Would definitely come back again and bring my whole family here

Parking around here can be rough
author: Julie N.

description: I've been coming here for years and love the manly dishes that I can't find elsewhere - steamed dumplings, crepe and many soups. There are times the dishes have been overly salted but otherwise it all tastes great!
author: M H.

description:
I miss this place .  .Definitely  put the Clay Pot Chicken on your bucket list !

 Their Crispy Chicken is the best Asian comfort food I've ever had !

 The Restaurant is cozy and welcoming as the friendly people who work there.

  Great food and service  


   C. N.       is the best !
author: Bay F.

description:
I have to say that the place is very simple and doesn't look as s cool place but.. They have some amazing food! This is my second time and I've had now the Vietnamese dumplings (AMAZING) and had a beef soup! Both were simply delicious and the portions are big enough to share.
Also positive: they serve food much later than other places in the neighborhood so if you had no food and searching for something good at a very reasonable price, this should be your choice!
author: Irina P.

description:
Hands down the best Vietnamese restaurant around town!  The interior is on the fancier side, not like those late night pho spots after a night of debauchery.

As a starter I high recommend the imperial rolls.

Of course, I went with the chicken pho. It was perfection, very fresh! I didn't even taste much msg.

The wait was not long at all either, or we might have just gotten lucky that night.

This is a repeat spot for me!
author: Michelle T.

description: We absolutely loved this place, despite the pretentious people that frequent this side of town.   We started with the appetizer sampler, which had spring rolls, egg rolls, and a delicious shrimp salad.  I'm not going to try to name what I had for dinner, but it was skirt steak and shrimp skewers with a lettuce salad.  Beef was tender and flavourful, and the shrimp was done perfectly.   My wife had some kind of shrimp in carmalized sauce, and it was good as well.   Service was excellent.   I would definitely go back.
author: Paul M.

description:
Came here for lunch on a weekday and there was no wait. The restaurant itself is spacious, beautifully decorated and in a nice neighborhood. The service is good but I think the food was average. 

We ordered the large bowl of beef pho ($9.50) and vermicelli grilled pork/imperial roll ($11.50). The vietnamese coffee drip was an interesting presentation but the main dishes were both just okay.

The prices for the serving size were on the high end in comparison to other Vietnamese restaurants so I would come back here for the ambiance mostly.
author: Linda X.

description:
Friendly and easy to make a reservation. Service was decently prompt---our water glasses were always topped up.

I would compare this place to a slightly nicer Tin (in SOMA). If you're looking for a nice date place and want Vietnamese, this is a good choice.

I only tried their imperial rolls and their bun cha goi thit nuong (imperial rolls and pork over vermicelli noodles). Both did not disappoint, though I did notice that the amount of pork/rolls was slightly smaller than at other, cheaper Vietnamese restaurants in Little Saigon. Their imperial rolls were also a little smaller than what I am used to.

If I lived in the area, this would probably be a go-to restaurant for me.
author: Yan F.

description: The food is amazing! I probably eat here once a week. I'm addicted. I've tried many dishes here, although I do have my favorite go-to dishes, and everything I've ordered so far has been phenomenal. I don't understand the few bad reviews...service is great and the food is good!
author: Katrina A.

description: The best Vietnamese food in the northeastern quadrant of the city, pro tip: get the pancake
author: Cainen G.

description: I've been a client at this restaurant since 1996! The quality and quantity of the food has always been on the rise. We love the "make your own" fresh rolls. The Salt and Pepper Shrimp in shell is always perfect in spiciness and flavor! We always close it with the fried banana with ice cream... all I can say is... YUM!
author: Nadine B.

description: Very tasty dishes! Had Cha Ca La Vong for the first time since being in Hanoi, and it did not disappoint. The cucumber prawn salad was also a nice refreshing start to the meal. Friendly and attentive staff, will definitely be back!
author: Andy L.

description: Ordered delivery and it took a loooong time to get here. . much longer than reported on grub hub originally.  The food was decent, but a large container of sauce had opened and turned sideways during delivery, so all of the food containers were soaked on the bottom with this sauce (and now missing all of that sauce to eat). . I would try again, but if delivery sucks again, totally not worth it.  Props to the bag company though!!  Didn't know it spilled till I opened up the package : (
author: Katie H.

description:
It was damp and cold and we all wanted some warm comfort food. Pho it is!

Place was near empty, but we were there a bit early for dinner. I think we beat the rush however, because by the time we finished, the place was pretty crowded.

Service was good, the staff was attentive and kept our water glasses full.

We had the sampler of appetizers that consisted of spring rolls, egg rolls and banh cuon. They only give you one banh cuon, but it was pretty good. I'd order a giant plate of banh cuon as a meal if I could.

Pho was ok. Nothing to write home about, but its not disgusting, just middle of the road.  The broth was clean, but it also meant it was a little lacking in flavor, so throw in the sauces and lime to fix that. Large bowl was more like a medium (at least compared to the bowls used in TX), but its ok, I get it, Cali is trying to conserve water and such...

Overall, not too shabby.
author: Anthony B.

description:
I love Aux Delices! Definitely one of my favorite restaurants in the city for inexpensive, fast, and good food. Their crispy sticky garlic chicken is uh-mazing. Such good flavor and texture. Their pho is great too - a little pricier than what you'd pay at other places, but worth it. I'm also a big fan of their crispy imperial rolls.

I much prefer dining at Aux Delices than ordering takeout/delivery. Something gets lost in the portion sizes, flavor, and consistency. Do yourself a favor and dine in!
author: Audrey A.

description:
This place is awesome!  Parking can be a bit difficult, but it's pretty good for SF.  You may have to walk a block or two, but there is usually street parking available and your experience will definitely be worth it.

Everything here gets 5 stars - I happen to know the family who owns this restaurant, so when I came here, they gave me extra spring rolls and garlic noodles.

When you first walk in, you realize this is a bit of a nice place - white tablecloth, nice candles, nice decorations on the wall, kind of small and intimate - the atmosphere is kind of romantic.  Service is very friendly and fast, and the portions are big - the first time I came here - I ordered a ribeye steak and was amazed at how big it was - plus a healthy (sizewise) portion of vegetables.  When I went to pay my bill, I was surprised to find it was only about $25 - very reasonable prices - and I would say great for SF because everything is so expensive here.

The second time I came here, I ordered the claypot with pork (I think) and brown rice.  It was so flavorful and sizzling hot, and the servers are so friendly - I really enjoyed my experience.  It helps that I was here with a very pretty girl (my girlfriend) on a date - and she liked it so much we went back last night.

So the first thing I'm doing this morning is giving Aux Delices 5 stars - and saying I will definitely be back!
author: Francis D.

description: Whenever I feel like eating Vietnamese food in SF, Aux Delices is my restaurant of choice (and I'm Vietnamese!)
author: Kim V.

description: Great neighborhood Vietnamese restaurant, like that they can remove fish sauce from plates too! Good for vegetarians.
author: Francesca P.

description:
The crepe, get it. This is as good as they get!

Some of the strongest vegetarian appetizers, not a huge selection of vegetarian mains. Not great for a gluten free diet.
author: Shannon Z.

description: So my BF has been talking about taking me here for dinner ever since we started dating. It finally happened last weekend! He did mention that parking is tough so he had his friend (Uber driver) drove us. We got there about 6pm on a Friday. A few people are eating - not so busy yet. He knew the lady who owns it (I believe "HA" was her name) so he said hi at the bar. She remembered him! She was a really nice lady. My bf decided that he will order the dishes by himself so I was like - OK. make sure they're really good. He goes, 'trust me on this'. We started with the Vietnamese Pancakes - I am not usually a fan (I usually go with spring rolls or egg rolls to start with) but these ones are flaky and tasty. For entrees: we had the Steak (BF ate it all since it was cooked Medium - i do my steak Medium Well), Garlic Noodles - so delicious and garlicky (just enough garlic - not too salty) and Crispy Chicken - this one was my FAVE. The BOMB.COM. The sauce was too good to be eaten on its own. The chicken was breaded and crispy even with the sauce. Unbelievably good. We ended our dinner with the flan as our dessert. I was going for the fried banana but the BF opted this one for a change. It was on the sweet side for me but heck, we ate the whole plate too! The place got busier as it got closer to dinner time. Over-all, the staff, the food and the ambiance is great! The prices of dishes are reasonable. ($12 and above) Where else in the city would get a chicken entree for $12 that is rated 5 stars?
author: Anna Y.

description:
As a huge fan of Vietnamese food, I left here disappointed. Nothing was bad by any means, it just wasn't anything special. And for the more expensive than usual prices, I just expected more. Better off going to one of the cheaper places-food is just the same. Interior is cheesy-fancy. 

Won't be back!
author: Sarah G.

description: A family owned restaurant with reasonable prices, excellent service and very good Vietnamese food. The restaurant is actually quiet enough so you can hear the people at your table. The owners are always there, are friendly and have excellent suggestions on what to order. I love their spicy soup, filet mignon and Vietnamese crepe.
author: Joan C.

description:
Tonight I ordered (prepared entirely gluten free)

(1) Banh Xeo - a savory pan fried crepe. I've grown up eating these so it was a no brainer for a starter! Super yummy.
(2) Cai Xanh Xao - broccoli with chicken, the garlic-i-ness was so on point!
(3) Bo Cari Thai - spicy beef curry was the highlight of the entire meal: Basil, bamboo, tofu, peppers, string beans... everything you can possibly want in a sizzling pot!
(4) Flourless chocolate cupcake with vanilla gelato - ok... You cannot opt out of this, please just trust me and save room for dessert when you try this restaurant. My mouth is watering just reliving the memory of eating this cake.

For having so many gluten free options, this place is awesome! :)
author: Amanda H.

description:
Crab & asparagus soup - The cup is perfect to share between 2 people. Excellent for a cold day.

Sampler (13) - imperial rolls, spring rolls, and dumplings. Perfect for sharing. Imperial rolls are one of my favorite things in the world so i have very high standards. These were decent at best. The spring rolls fell apart pretty easily. 

Banh Xeo - Viet crepe stuffed with bean sprouts and pork. Crispy perfection. One of my favorite viet comfort foods for sure.

Shaking beef (20) - Not the best quality but it is delicious nonetheless. Garlicky and flavorful!

Garlic Noodles - A lot better than I expected. Bursting with garlic flavor.

This place is pricier than the Viet restaurants I usually go to but that's because it's nicer than what you'll find in the TL. It was pretty empty at 7PM on Friday night, but was packed by 8.
author: Lucy N.

description:
Best Vietnamese restaurant for sure! I work around this area and found this treasure. Their food is flavored and really delicious. I wish they open at 11am (: 

The lady waitress is good and fast at serving food. she cares for her customer a lot.
author: River D.

description:
This place is a good place to hit when you want to go to an asian place after 9pm. Not all of the dishes were amazing.

Recmmended:
Xup Mang Cua - crab asparagus. crab, asparagus & egg scrambled in a thick broth -- clean flavorful soup which is great for a cold night or after a long flight

Cha Ca -- grilled basa filet over fresh dill & green onions topped with caramelized onions served with rice noodles, vegetable and peanuts -- this is probably my favorite dish out of the meal. super tender fish. good balance of flavors, not too heavy or saucy. 

Mediocre:
Goi Du Du spicy green papaya -- shredded green papaya with calamari tossed with mint, cilantro and tomatoes -- OK dish, like the thai version of this better.

Avoid:
Dau Hu Xao Rau-- fried or fresh tofu sauteed with vegetables & black mushrooms in a garlic & ginger sauce -- this is what I would call an Americanized version of a Chinese dish. not super fresh and ingredients are mediocre.
author: Rebecca C.

description: Nice, lower key alternative to Slanted Door - and just as good. Love the glass noodle with crab and shrimp, so amazing. Lychee martini was pretty tasty too. Bonus: just cross the street for Loving Cup for dessert!
author: Luxxury L.

description: I enjoyed dining here, the ambience was warm and inviting. The crepe was delicious! I never had anything like it before- it was a fried shell stuffed with chicken and shrimp and came with a delicious fish sauce dip with lettuce wraps. I didn't enjoy the clay pot caramel salmon as much- it was a bit too sweet and overwhelming; if you get this make sure to get a good helping of rice. The flourless chocolate cupcake was amazing though, a nice ending to a great meal. The chocolate was warm and gooey.
author: Anna C.

description:
My family had dinner at Aux Delices last week while in town on vacation. We were staying in the neighborhood and walked by several times before deciding to stop in for dinner, in part because we were apprehensive about taking our 9 month old son to an "upscale" place.

We were more than delighted by the service we received. The staff was extremely considerate of our son's needs: his highchair was placed on a tablecloth when we were seated, and he was given a sippy cup of water and a small bowl of chicken porridge without us requesting either. He ate all of the porridge and clamored for bites of our food as well!

And the food! My partner loves salmon but I hate it, so he makes a point to order it when we're out. He raved about his Caramel Salmon and insisted that I try it. Let me go on the record as saying that the only time I have ever had salmon that I could tolerate, much less enjoy, was at Charlie Trotter (RIP). That is, until I tried his Caramel Salmon. I don't know that I would order it for myself, but I enjoyed what I tried, and would try it again. And that is about the highest possible compliment I could give to salmon. I had the Bun Cha Gio Thit Nuong - also delicious, but not as noteworthy as the Caramel Salmon. We finished with the fried bananas, which our son also devoured.

Traveling with a small baby is hard, and dining out with a small baby is even harder. It's rare that a nice restaurant also makes kids feel welcome. It's even rarer that a nice restaurant where kids feel welcome also has food that both adults and kids will enjoy. I'm so glad we stumbled on Aux Delices, and am only sad we didn't make it back during our visit.
author: Elizabeth E.

description:
I've only had the chicken pho in chicken broth & spring rolls here, but I really like them both ... Make sure to add sriracha, bean sprouts, jalapeños and lime to the pho. it's definitely my go to on cold nights. Feeling under the weather tonight so calling in an order now! 

I always take the food to go too, it's always so hot in the restaurant.
author: danielle a.

description: The food here is done just right. If you're looking for good Vietnamese in a nice atmosphere this is the right place. The vegetarian spring rolls are great. We ordered the garlic noodles, basa fish clay pot, and crispy chicken. I highly recommend the basa fish as well as the crispy chicken. The noodles were good but what I've noticed is that most Vietnamese places that serve garlic noodles serve the noodles pretty soft which I'm not crazy about.  As far as flavor they were very garlicky and good. We would definitely come back here.
author: Yasi N.

description: My favorite Vietnamese place in the city.  I've been here over 30 times and it's always a great experience.  I would recommend the sampler platter, pho, and spicy chicken with onions and bell peppers.
author: Matt M.

description: My Dad and I ordered Hu Tieu (Seafood soup) pitiful portion, bad quality ingredients. Decent broth I guess. What can I expect out of Russian Hill though? Go to the TL to Pho 2000 if you want some good Pho. This is Vietnamese food for white people who are afraid of seasoning
author: Max J.

description: Restaurant was busy so an hour and a half later I received cold food.  It wasn't particularly exciting for the price and I wouldn't order from here again, unfortunately.
author: Claire C.

description:
I just finished eating dinner here with some friends and all I have to say is that.. This place is so bad that I have to write a review!

Initially, we wanted to go to Leopold's, but the wait was 2 hours long! We were really hungry so we didn't wait. I decided to Yelp for places to eat around the area and came upon this place. I should've taken the hint when I didn't see any Asians. The restaurant itself was nice. The waiters were attentive - TOO attentive I must say (my glass of water was refilled constantly).

We ordered the xup mang cua - crab asparagus soup (nothing special), Canard L'Orange (absolutely no flavor with a weird smell of orange), shaken beef (overcooked and not enough flavor) and ca kho (tasted burnt and not sweet enough as it should be).

Overall, if you want authentic Vietnamese food, DO NOT COME HERE! The pricing was a bit pricey for Vietnamese food as well. For the price we paid, you'd think that the food would be at least mediocre.
author: Wendy P.

description:
Do not take your children here!
we walk in at 5pm on a sunday. it is empty, not one single person inside. we ask for a table for 3. Me, my husband and my 2 year old daughter (who is in my arms and silent.)

we ask to sit at one table in the corner. woman responds, no that is too big for 3 people. i have a table for you in the back. we ask for a smaller 2 person table up front that we can add a high chair to (plenty of room for another chair). she says no. I ask what the problem is, stating that the restaurant is literally empty and i don't understand why we can't have a choice of seats, and ask where she wants us to sit. She says the back as "we might get busy later and the child could be noisy." 

after a few choice words of how absurd she is I walk to the back where a managerial looking older gentleman is, along with a waitress and someone else lying horizontal (literally) on the long booth bench, and let them know that it is not only offensive, but it is stupid business. each of them stood there completely dumbfounded and had nothing to say, not a word. how on earth does this place survive without a shred of capability of speaking to a customer and dealing w/ a conflict that should've easily been resolved???

not that it should even matter but we eat out all the time, our daughter is very well behaved, was literally silent through this entire episode and if on chance she becomes antsy or loud, that is our queue to take her outside and deal as normal adults would. It is completely absurd that this restaurant is so ridiculous toward a child and so rude to customers. and stupid, considering not a single soul was in the restaurant they clearly aren't concerned with making any money. 

there are plenty of restaurants in this city to take our business to. we will not be back.
author: K C.

description:
Bad experience dinning here. Probably why it was only half full on a Saturday night. 

Ordered the garlic noodles, pho, and grilled pork with fried rice. All the dishes were mediocre except the garlic noodles. Garlic noodles was okay but lack ingredients. 

Pho broth was bland. 

Grilled pork was delicious in flavor but thinly sliced and slightly burnt on the edges. 
The fried rice was horrible. It tasted like white rice with oil and had chunks where  the rice was overcooked.

The worst was the service where they kept eyeing the table even tho we were still working on the food. We had to tell them at least 3 times that we were still using the sauces to go with the Pho. 

The restaurant also has a minimum charge of $10 per person and extra fees if you are using more than one credit card. 

For a place that is charging more than a regular authentic Vietnamese restaurant, I expected better food and/ or service. But both we
author: WQ C.

description:
4 stars on the cuisine and service.  BBQ sampler was the bomb with delicious skewer or beef and crispy imperial rolls.  Also the rice and garlic chicken with veggies.
Lunch Special = plenty of variety, great prices!
author: CraigsBay209 ..

description: This place is OK....food didn't wow me like other Vietnamese places I have fallen in love with (Turtle Tower, Cafe Bun Mi, or Seattle places like Babar, Green Leaf, Monkey Bridge, or Tamarind Tree). Nothing incredible to rave about, but worth going to if you live close by. Super clean on the inside and the staff is very friendly.
author: Lyle Z.

description:
Russian Hill is a great area for good restaurants to try in San Francisco. 
We picked Aux Delices since we like Vietnamese food a lot.
The place is bigger than it looks in pictures, it goes way back. I expected a hole in the wall and it's not.  The decor is nice, chic, modern Asian, warm, cozy and elegant. Great place for a date or for a night out with friends. Service was good.

We got the garlic noodles (very good), my husband got the Ga Kho (chicken in a caramel sauce served in a clay pot) which was sooo tasty and I got Bo Xao Gung Va Xa (beef sauteed with ginger & lemongrass). We shared a big bottle of Tsingtao beer.
The food was very good, flavorful, we wished that my beef and the garlic noodles were hotter.

For desert we shared their flour less chocolate cupcake with Indonesian Cinnamon gelato! Outstanding!

Cute place (not touristy), great food, we enjoyed our dinner here.
author: Jo S.

description:
I was in Japan for more than a month, just came back with a great craving for beef. Even though I am from Kobe, mecca of Kobe beef, I needed the real kind. 
My gf told me that maybe I need more iron, because I'm eating too much raw fish. So we came here for dinner the other night. I saw a guy having the steak, so I ordered it. 

In my opinion, it is really one of their best items.
#47 Bifteck Braise, 20 bucks!
Charbroiled Rib Eye Steak, cooked with butter and garlic served with vegetables. 
The steak is way better than the description; it was tender and juicy!
SO GOOD!
I like Viet-food very much but let me say that I am not really big fan of pho. I can eat it, but .... every time my friend took me to eat pho, I always fell not satisfied, because I need more my head bouncing my eyes rolling my nose running my ass poking strong flavor.
I have to eat Ramen every time after I had pho. So, I'll eat it if you insist, but it's not my kind.
And egg roll, spring roll are, to me, it's a side-walk finger food. 
And the way too milky sweet dripping coffee is not my kind, because I hate milk.
Milk Doesn't Do Any Good! 

So, come to the #47, the Rib Eye Steak.
It was a hidden secret item for almost forever!
I loved every single bite.
I am so happy finding this great steak.
What a great surprise!
An unexpected, astonishing, impressive and amazing!
5 star item in the city!
author: Nobu K.

description:
Stopped off here for dinner with one of my bridesmaids and I had eyeing this place for some time.  The food here is reasonably priced, and they do delivery!  Placed nicely on upper Polk, this place is convenient if you live in the area.  After sitting down, we decided to share the following:

Appetizer:
Imperial Rolls: Fried rolls with pork, chicken, bean thread noodles, mushrooms & vegetables served with lettuce, mint and fish sauce.  HOLY COW. I'm always a fan of Vietnamese spring rolls and when it's fried, it makes things THAT much better!

Mains:
Heo Va Tom Kho: Pork & Prawns in a caramel sauce served in a clay pot. SO DELICIOUS! We couldn't decide on what type of protein we wanted between pork and shrimp, so we got both! 

Bun Bo Xao: Sauteed beef noodle bowl.  Your standard noodle bowl, but with delicious beef, lemongrass, and onion.

Our total for this came out to something around $30 each.  I mean, we got SO much food for that, so Aux Delices is definitely efficient when it comes to how much you get for your money!  Having had their delivery before, I definitely think it's better to go in and sit down and enjoy things like their clay pot dishes since it comes out piping hot!  Awesome little spot in Russian Hill!
author: Lisa I.

description: Almost no vegetarian food here anymore - I was super upset when I came here with a group of friends based on their online menu and found they have completely changed it and removed most of their good looking veggie options. :( I eventually decided on one dish with fried tofu - was unfortunately painfully bland.
author: Rekha J.

description: Coming to this restaurant is just by accident,  but I was really surprised how amazing they are. Love the fish and steak they served, kind of like the taste in the childhood in China, fish cooked by mum. Also environment is also nice, highly recommend for couples.
author: Jie Z.

description:
We came here on a weekend expecting a long line out the door and was pleasantly surprised we were seated right away. Luckily we got there 5 minutes til 6 because when we looked back, a line was out the door.

Great service and staff, they were very attentive, my water glass was constantly filled as I drink water like a fish.

We ordered the Sampler, which was awesome, we got two imperial rolls, two spring rolls, and rice noodles with meat and shrimp filling. The best thing about this place is they make sure you have the full Vietnamese dinning experience by having fresh lettuce, herbs, and dipping sauce for each dish. 

We got a cup of Pho Ga (chicken noodle soup). Even though it was a beef broth, the chicken was perfect and they got the beef broth just right. with a squirt of lime and a few herbs this was the perfect way to start our meal. 

Cha Ca-( Grilled Basa Filet over fresh dill & green onions topped with caramelized onions served with rice noodles, vegetable and peanuts) 

This was our main dish, I've been craving it since I've move up from Los Angeles and I'm so glad they have this dish because they execute it perfectly! The only thing peole might not like is the dipping sauce that comes with it because its the traditional fish paste  sauce. If you don't like the sauce then I suggest you ask for the fish sauce that comes with the imperial rolls. The dish will still taste amazing.
author: Michael S.

description:
Absolute neighborhood gem. For so many reasons.

1. Consistency: always delicious, honors old dishes etc.
2. Service: kind, efficient, unobtrusive, helpful (if needed)
3. Quality/Product: excellent, authentic, creative + simplicity combined
4. Value: Beyond wonderful- I'm always floored (in a good way) when the bill arrives

Aux Delices is a place you can be relaxed with a friend, or celebrate a life event. It has this great ambiance of 'pick your mood' which is a really nice.
author: Meredith R.

description:
Tried the delivery service tonight since we were staying at the Sheraton Hotel.  They charge $5.00 for delivery and it was estimated to be 45-75 minutes.  I did not mind since I was feeling sick and did not want to go anywhere else.  Nothing that Pho would not cure.

The food:  They have a limited selection of Pho to choose from.  Not what I was use to in Sacramento down Stockton blvd.  I tried the Beef pho and it was ok.  NOt the best, but ok.

Also tried the spicy crispy chicken.  It was good.  It was spicy and sweet.  Kind of like a garlic sauce to it.

Also tried the Banh xeo.  We requested it to be extra crispy and it was PERFECT.  

Totally acceptable place.  Would recommend to others.
author: Heidi H.

description: This place is a gem. Consistently solid and rarely a wait. Their Pho is fresh and delicious. The ambiance is also nice. It's got a more upscale feel without spending a ton.
author: Katie S.

description: Delicious food and incredible service. We will be back! We loved the chicken with vermicelli noodles. The pork was amazing!
author: Jill H.

description:
The first time I visited, I ordered the Vietnamese steamed dumplings that my friend recommended not realizing that they're not really dumplings but the Vietnamese steamed rice rolls that my parents like to buy from San Jose's Little Saigon. For $8, I thought that Aux Delices' version paled in comparison to the more authentic banh cuon I've had in San Jose and in Vietnam. 

However, I did hear that they make a good version of Hanoi's signature dish, cha ca (grilled fish), which I regret not trying when I was in Hanoi, so I returned to give that a try. This dish was delicious and worth the $14! The grilled white fish fillet was served in a hot clay pot with fresh dill, green onions, caramelized onions, rice noodles, peanuts, and an anchovy sauce dip. I requested for rice paper wraps which they didn't charge me extra for and which tasted great with the dish. I'll definitely return to eat the cha ca again.
author: Diana B.

description:
It was alright Vietnamese food nothing like my mom's but good.  Ca Kho had way too many bones and was super oily.  Sampler platter with Goi Cuon, Cha Gio, and Banh Cuon was standard run of the mill.  Pho broth was weak and barely got any meat.  Maybe I'm just spoiled by my mom's restaurant in Virginia and frequently have been to Orange County and Vietnam.

I'm sure it's considered great for the general population though.
author: Jay H.

description: The service was terrible. We had a group, and a couple of us did not order anything. The waitress gave us an obnoxious attitude, even asking us, "Oh then why are you here?" When someone decided to order something a bit later, she then made another snide comment, "Oh NOW you order something?" The food was itself quite bland, unimpressive, and the portions were small. Overall a terrible experience. I would avoid this place at all cost, if for no other reason than the bad service alone.
author: Hui H.

description: I had the vegetable Curry with chicken (#28). So amazingly good! Veggies were fresh and crisp, chicken breast was tender, juicy, and well-seasoned. The atmosphere is warm and friendly and the decor is classy. Service was friendly and attentive. Wholeheartedly recommend this place!
author: Sheena C.

description: Ordered take out that was over $70 and waited for more than an hour so I called the restaurant to see what was going on.  The person who picked up lied and said they never received the order and to call EAT24. I tried calling back several times just to get a busy dial tone - pretty sure they left the phone off the hook on purpose so I couldn't get through.  Finally got a call back from EAT24 where they told me that the order went through and was all prepared but they just didn't want to deliver it! Such bullshit.
author: Mei W.

description: Super fast service, polite workers, food comes out fast, huge plates, best soup ever (Nr 6 on the menu)!! Love this place!
author: Tone B.

description: This place is wack, pho bowl size is too small and over priced I don't recommend this place you're better off going to another place!!!
author: Slim T.

description:
A year ago I would have given them 4 stars, but those days are over.  The service is awful and the food isn't much better.  There are 5 employees, and there were only 7 tables, but we still waited forever for everything, including the bill.  

They did not check on us once to ask if the meal was ok, and we had to flag people down for literally everything even though we were sitting next to the service area.  Meanwhile some of the employees were busy bullshitting with their friends that were at a nearby table.  General demeanor is that they could not give a F.  They got a 10% tip, when they really deserved nothing.  I've gotten better service at virtually every restaurant on Polk St.  This restaurant completely sucks.
author: Adam S.

description:
This  place is actually pretty good. We were debating between here and lemongrass but figured Vietnamese was a good change. 

Got the imperial rolls which were very good, papaya salad which was good but too expensive in my opinion.

The beef satay was amazing. Flavorful and huge portion.

Overall I'd come back. Easy solid choice right in the neighborhood.
author: Michelle A.

description:
Vegetarians BEWARE. 

We went to this place specifically because they had a whole vegetarian section on the menu. So I ordered the veg spring rolls (which were fine) and the mixed vegetable soup in clear broth. The soup arrived and I took one small taste--chicken broth. After a bit of effort, we got the waitress back to the table and I asked her if they had vegetable soup with CLEAR broth (as was stated on the menu). She seemed rather confused by this request for some reason, and after several attempts at explaining, I thought she understood. She came back 2 minutes later with another bowl of soup in clear broth. Well, let me tell you what they must have done--ladeled off my vegetables which had been soaking in the nasty chicken broth, and plopped them into hot water. Gross.

The restaurant has no idea that I was dissatisfied (unless the waitress paid attention to the tiny tip) because there was no follow-up AT ALL. Crappiest service I've had in years.
author: Melissa M.

description: Came in for lunch and had the medium sized beef pho and it was delicious! The broth was really flavorful. A little saltier than I'm used to but not in a bad way. The place settings are nice and clean here. They also played great music and had good service. I live in the area so will definitely come back and bring others in with me.
author: Julie T.

description:
It's a family-run business and the pho bo (beef pho) is okay. Decent but not amazing. I did ask if they use MSG and they said they do use a "little bit". I'm not sure what that means but for those of you who are allergic, please be aware. I wish places would stop using it. It really doesn't do much for the food. Their broth was pretty bland. They also don't give cilantro just basil, lots of sprouts and jalapeno slices. It's a decent place if you're craving pho and you can't get it elsewhere but I wouldn't go out of my way for it.

I also had the cha gio (egg rolls). The style is correct and these were a good flavor but chewy not crisp. I also had the spring rolls. These were also good but I've had better.
author: Bunny C.

description:
This review has been log overdue!

My family has been coming here since they were dating in the 1980's. The owner and his daughter knows us as the family who always orders 1 steak each, the "Bifteck Braise" hahah BECAUSE IT'S THAT GOOD! This item is truly one of their best hidden secrets. Trust me (and my parents, my 4 siblings, and husband), the steak is way better than the decription - cooked with garlic and butter and is always tender and juicy no matter what served with veggies! So good!

Our second favorite item on the menu are the imperial rolls - perfectly crispy on the outside! We also love ordering the different clay pot items, the chicken bean noodle soup, beef thai salad, papaya salad... pretty much anything here is delicious and you really can't go wrong.

Over the years, Aux Delices is still my most favorite Vietnamese restaurant. It definitely helps that the ambiance is relaxing and is exceptionally clean for an asian restaurant. Cheers to you all for sustaining such a great business after all these years!
author: Trina D.

description:
Big deal
way over-rated!
author: Kevin F.

description: We have been to Aux Delices before, but didn't think much of the place or the food. Recently, we didn't know where to eat and decided to read Yelp for inspiration. After reading all the rave reviews on the steak at Aux Delices, we decided to order it, and we are so glad we did! Super yummy meal and the steak was just superb! The other dish (Heo Va Tom Kho...Pork & Prawns in a caramel sauce served in a clay pot) was good but too sweet for my taste. We will definitely order the steak again in the near future!
author: Missy X.

description:
The street on which you will find Aux Delices is not like others in SF. It is calm, with doggies outside and a modest amount of foot traffic. On a weekday lunch, Aux Delices was relatively empty. 

First out was chao (rice porridge) that comes every meal. Warm, comforting, something that you can eat when it's cold outside or you're sick and stuck inside. 

I ended up ordering the green mango salad, which tasted quite fresh and citrus-y with a good fish sauce kick. 

Perhaps the arduous and unnecessary trek up a steep flight of stairs and walking around lost leads me to recalling Aux Delices with a bit of a sour note. If I'm ever back in the neighborhood and craving Vietnamese, I may give it another try, but I will not make it a point to revisit.
author: Shirley V.

description:
The imperial rolls were AH-MAZ-ZING!!!! I'm visiting from LA and these rolls brought me back to my visit to Vietnam 10 years ago! soooo tasty!  a MUST try.
The Garlic Noodles and 5 spice chicken were also delicious!
author: Emi G.

description:
This is a family run Vietnamese restaurant located on Russian Hill. When I came here with a friend a few days ago it was very busy but we were seated quickly. I don't know much about Vietnamese food beyond pho, so I wasn't sure what to to order. The menu was pretty user friendly and I ended up ordering a glass noodle dish with veggies in a garlic and ginger sauce. The dish itself wasn't to my liking but it was well cooked and the vegetables were fresh. My friend had the pho and I tried it and it was good. 

The restaurant is well decorated and seems to attract a mostly local crowd. The service is a little slow but they are busy and it's to be expected. We also tried the thai iced teas and of course, they were delicious. Everyone seemed to be enjoying the food and the staff was upbeat and happy. That says a lot about a restaurant. Will definetely return.
author: Sam W.

description: Some of the best vietnamese food you can get in SF.  I've been coming here for years and it's never been a disappointment.  Try the Pho Ga (chicken pho) and the Tom Rang Muoi (flash fried shrimp).
author: Steve C.

description:
Since moving to the Bay area, I've been here a number of times and the food, service, experience has been consistently good. New items that I love are the garlic noodles, the loc lac, bahn cuon (yumm!), bahn xeo (crispy crepe), and my favorite: beef satay.

Everything on the menu is delicious -- you really can't go wrong. The service is great and the prices are wonderful. Glad that I live within walking distance! YUM!
author: Siv L.

description: Stopped in at 5:30pm on a Saturday after a long day of volunteering at the chocolate festival. Only 2 other tables were there so sat right down in the front. The service was friendly - although I don't think the server was too happy that we each just ordered one item. I had the glass noodles with shrimp and crab - they were delicious. Daughter had garlic noodles and they could have been more garlicky. She liked her apple cider and I loved that they had a stout beer on the menu - that surprised me. I'd definitely go back and try many more menu items.
author: Laurie H.

description:
Overall Impression: A lovely setting, good food, and a perfect spot for a first date.

Cost: Probably as much as you will ever pay for Vietnamese cuisine... and still very affordable.

Taste/Presentation: Chicken and beef pho were on point. The shaking beef (Bo Luc Lac) that everyone else is raving about was indeed the highlight of the menu. The meat is SUPER tender and melts in your mouth! 

Customer Service: Very attentive and courteous. The standard stuff.

Ambience/Atmosphere:  Very diverse crowd. People young and old come here. More of an intimate/formal setting, but no one will stare if you come with a T-shirt and shorts.
author: Kevin T.

description:
It's official, this is my new neighborhood favorite.  I've had to have passed it 100 times - how?  

It's small, cute, and the food is delices!  I am slowly but surely working my way through the menu here and was pleasantly impressed with my dine in experience.  Sure, I've had their delivery but the ambiance is dine-in worthy - bamboo zen - cute.  Good birthday or date spot.

Tonight we ordered:
(1) caramel salmon - served piping hot in a clay pot - sweet spicy sort of like a tangy teriyaki but better.  I love love loved this. 
(2) leeche sake martini- generous in size
(3) imperial roll - even better than I remember last time - still the best
(4) papaya salad with calamari this time - outstanding - the calamari is sliced into super slim strips not rings
(5) ginger lemongrass beef - tender yum
(6) jasmine rice - perfect
(7) chocolate cupcake with Indonesian cinnamon gelato "frosting" which is basically a cupcake a la mode. BANG'n.  Not super chocolaty but more buttery and served warm so your gelato gets all over the place - yeahhh.  
(8) Malbec - they have a really decent wine glass list and even more extensive list of bottles.

We were seated right away, without a reservation.  The service was fast, but not push you out the door quick.  The food was timed right and flowed.  I was so into my plate that I forgot to peep what others had ordered, but caught a few dishes.  Pho, beef on a stick, creme brulee with passion fruit sorbet looked yummy. 

 I love the food and really want to try it all, but I could also see myself stopping in just for dessert.
author: Rayna A.

description:
NOTE: I'm sipping on my pho as I write.

I needed to point that out because this pho is soo good. I've never heard of pho until I moved out here to SF( ignorant, maybe so). Reading reviews from my fellow yelpers, everyone talks about how tasty pho is. I just landed in SF on a red-eye flying from NY and was feeling in the dumps. I decided to order pho from here( 2 blocks away from my apt), and I am in love. The medium is huge. It will defiantly fill you up. I'll save the rest for tomorrow. I'm having a sneezing/coughing fit now so this is where I will end my review.
author: Court S.

description:
My go-to place for solid Vietnamese cuisine.   Even though the service is pretty limited, the ambience is pleasant and the food is flavorful.  They have a wide variety of dishes including plenty of vegetarian options.  

Even though their traditional pho is delicious, I prefer their soup called "canh chua", a spicy lemongrass soup with bean sprouts, tomatoes, pineapple, mushrooms, basil, and meat/tofu.  It's amazingly delicious.  I also always order the papaya salad which has a good balance of tangy and spicy. 

Overall, this is a perfect spot for a chilly San Francisco evening!
author: Juliana K.

description:
Ugg - Never ever eating here again.  Order the Papaya Salad with Shrimp on Thursday  6/12/14  - and have been sick all weekend.   Ordered take out  - and between the 4 of us - 2 got food poisoning. The common item was the Papaya Salad.  On top of that - who ever was taking the orders was fairly rude and didn't like answering my questions. 
Skip this place
author: David E.

description:
Expectations were high as the place was pretty packed at 8 PM on a Wednesday.  My eating partner in crime and I had just arrived in San Francisco after being in Mexico for a week.  We were incredibly excited to finally eat something Asian.  Expectations went even higher when a regular there had reaffirmed that this was the best Vietnamese place in the city.

For whatever reason, about half way through the meal, I came to this sad realization that everything reminded me of Chinese takeout.  Harsh, I know.  The garlic noodles aren't much more than garlic flavored lo mein, while the crispy chicken in sticky sauce struck an oh too familiar chord with general tso's chicken.

I will say that the imperial rolls are some of the best damn spring rolls I've ever had any place, anywhere.  Each one is filled to the brim with meat and noodles, with a very slight and unoffensive hint of fish sauce.

The wine is reasonably priced but I would stay away from the twist off bottles.
author: Philip F.

description:
You know, Aux Delices, you aright after all. 

Came here w/ my parents because they wanted Asian food nearby (because let's be real--they don't really eat anything else) and didn't want to walk any hils. So you can imagine our choices were limited in Russian Hill! 

So we walked to Aux Delices and decided to give it another try. We had:

-Cha ca: Grilled fish w/ onions served in a hot stone pot that you assemble as a lettuce wrap with vermicelli noodles, cilantro, and a special sauce. DAMN DELICIOUS! It's a little labor-intensive if you're lazy, but otherwise very much worth it. It can get a bit messy, so wouldn't order this on a first date, but I was w/ my parents so idgaf. 

-Imperial rolls: Served pretty much just like the cha ca, to be eaten wrapped w/ lettuce, pickled veggies and that fish sauce. I've never eaten it this way, but it should always be served like this! 

-Garlic noodles + chicken: Huge hit at the table and went perfectly w/ the added chicken. I honestly think it would be a bit boring without the chicken, but of course this is a side dish. 

So would I willingly go back? Probably for a weeknight dinner, or if my parents came to visit and didn't want to venture to Clement Street.

Overall, worth a try for Vietnamese in Russian Hill--just venture off into the less common dishes like pho.
author: Allison C.

description: The food was delicious and service was good. We ordered #30, #33, and the garlic noodles.
author: K W.

description:
Excellent family run restaurant.  Went there for dinner tonight.  The sampler platter of appetizers was delectable.  The green papaya salad was just spicy enough and the shrimp topped it off.  The garlic noodles were delectable.  The cubed filet beef with onions was so tender and savory it melts in your mouth. We also had the vegetable curry which was  perfectly seasoned with the veggies cooked just right.  To top it all off the service was impeccable which always my pet peeve.  

I would completely recommend eating here when in The City.  I will definitely be back here'
author: Roger Y.

description: We ordered online and picked the food up on the way home. It was ready, hot and packaged securely, at the advertised time. The food was very high quality! We had a soup, a noodle based dish and one other item that I can remember. It was light and fresh, delicately seasoned.
author: Sharon W.

description:
Yum! 

I love ordering take out from this place.

Their Pho is delicious as are the garlic noodles and appetizer platter.

Great spot on Polk for an easy night out.
author: Michelle K.

description:
No good.  I ordered Ca Phe Sue Da (the iced coffee that drip-brews on your table), and Grilled Pork with an Imperial roll and fried rice.  I got what I ordered, but not what I wanted: the pork consisted of 3-4 thin slices -- there was probably more pork in the Imperial Roll than on the plate.  Speaking of the Imperial Roll, it had a strange musty taste, as if the wrappers were stored in my grandmother's basement.  The fried rice?  Bland and soggy.

But the surprise of the evening was the coffee.  When it was served, the waiter asked "you know how to do it?"  I gave him a strange look, but a polite "yes".  5-10 minutes later, the coffee hadn't even stopped dripping when he shows up to take the brewing part away.  I said it's not done, and he said "no, I take this part" and walked off with it.

You don't use the word "no" to a customer without good reason.  You don't take something from a customer's table when they're not done with it.  Zero tip and one star.
author: Captain A.

description:
As an experiment, I went against all forms of instinct....and pretended to be a pseudo "tourist" and someone who is heavily reliant on Yelp for guidance and food tips. For once I was $hafted pretty hard! :-o. 

Did a quick search for Vietnamese in the city and looked at the hits. Aux Delices (The Delights?) came up with lots of positive write-ups of people who are connected to me. OK that's a start.

Whipped up the trusty Yelp app on the Winblows Phone Nokia Lumia 920 (don't hate, it takes great pictures...but the app still needs further improvement) and decided to order the "Yelp tourist" tried and true dishes based on the tip$ offered.

The menu has a pretty broad spectrum, and doesn't appear to be your average pho and spring rolls shop. But it is also not like those fancy fusion super upscale type places either.

6 pm on a Saturday night, and while parking was extremely scarce, the restaurant was otherwise rather quiet. 

Pho Tai - comes in three sizes....tall, grande, venti. The "tall" size would be ok for a quick snack portion, kind of like really traditional old style won ton noodle shops in Hong Kong like Mak's on Wellington St in Central. Asked about other beef cuts, like tendon. Denied. Just straight up beef...and the beef was rather chewy and dry. At these prices and rent I'm not expecting fresh unfrozen beef but hey... decent broth, with bare minimal MSG if any, ok noodles, but mediocre beef. Recommended if you are not an adventurous eater.

Garlic noodles - The toned down butter presence is perhaps heathier, but really needed more of a garlic kick. Otherwise this was saved (by me) with some non rooster chili sauce (which they provided in a little cylindrical holder with a spoon on the side).

Bo Luc Lac - Despite knowing that I might butcher the language, but not in a bad way, I ordered "Bo Luc Laaahc" with the Vietnamese waiter. And he replied back "oh you want the Shaking Beef" in his heavily accented English. I was like ok dude, whatever, I tried. So.....I need to ask, is there a difference between Bo Luc Lac and Shaking Beef? The same dish right? Well something was missing... BLL/SB  should be a no brainer filet mignon cubes stir fried and perfectly seasoned, juicy, medium rare, and have that killer umami from the soy sauce and other seasonings (hell you can put Maggi sauce and cook that till the cows come home, as long as it is good). After having ridiculous beef stir fry dishes by the greats (Yums Bistro and Ming Kee's former stir fry chef), this was a complete let down. All I tasted was soy sauce, not enough black pepper and other seasonings, and a lack of an intensive wok sear and carmelization. DOH! (and that does not mean "dude" in gangsta speak).

The cha gio (fried spring rolls) I had were equally puzzling. Very dry and the exterior seemed a bit too solid and thick. Of course I wasn't expected the rice paper roll version fried. But is this neighborhood scared of fish sauce? It was not served with any (granted the cha gio were sampled from another bbq pork rice plate) and even some weak fish sauce would have improved the taste of the dry cha gio a bit.

Ordered a café sua da (Vietnamese iced coffee with condensed milk) and apparently it was forgotten until the end of the meal. I purposely did not ask to remind them since the meal wasn't exactly my style with the way it was going, but later waitstaff came back and apologized....so I got it in a to go cup. Not bad...at least it was indeed the drip kind (but already mixed and poured in), and not the vanilla caramel latte stuff like Lee's or Brodard in the OC.

I'm not going to be the person who blames other reviewers for their good reviews.
But one thing of note, the 5 star glory days are mostly from 5 to 6 years back. Hmmm...
 
Perhaps for lack of other options as well as the neighborhood this place is in, this would be ok. But absolutely not my style. For a better price point, Ben Tre for example, which is closer to me, is a better place (and I don't even like Ben Tre that much).
author: Ken K.

description: An excellent dining option on Polk. At it's core it's Mom and Pop Vietnamese, but the ambiance isn't typical for a Mom and Pop, it's a bit more elegant... so you're fine bringing a date here, etc. I had the crispy rolls and the pho, both satisfied my hunger and longing for Vietnamese comfort food. Service was great and everybody in our group left happy and satisfied. Looking forward to next time.
author: Jeremy S.

description:
kinda bumpy reception as the hostess wasn't sure to where to seat us two.

The menu does not exude Authentic Vietnamese Cuisine and my better-half who was craving for AVC suggested we have a drink and a quick bite and bail. So we ordered a Chard n an IPA with Imperial Rolls.

Drinks arrived!

Then the IR... my wife went from a skeptic to an instant fan.

So we ended up having dinner as well and were not disappointed.

Though they need to work on presentation - Menu (layout), plating and Ambiance.
author: Madhusudhan R.

description: Decent food. Pho was really good along with the spring rolls and dumplings. The brown rice we ordered had a funky smell though so we switched out to white rice. Garlic noodles were okay nothing fantastic.
author: Alice P.

description:
I love Vietnamese food, but found that this restaurant catered more to those unfamiliar with it, and....tourists.

The mom and pop setting along with lovely decorations were great but I'd rather venture out to Little Saigon for more authentic flavors.
author: Veda R.

description:
Technically this 3 star is a 3.5 star... but Yelp won't let me do that... So, 3 stars it is.

Went here on a Friday night, as I was with a friend and meeting my girlfriend who had arrived separately, and early, and would not be seated until 'the rest of the guests' had arrived... Pet peeve, but, yeah... I get it.

First impressions were: 

- Clean dining room
- Decent ambience 
- Quick/friendly service
- Large menu

We had one pescatarian, and one genetically predisposed hater of cilantro, so the first test was having the fresh spring rolls sans pork, and sans cilantro. Waiter didn't flinch, just said ok - no problem. First test passed... 

Rolls arrived quickly! Shortly after our promptly served bottle of wine & beer, complete with a crisp, frosty beer mug. Bonus points here.... (I love frosty glasses) The rolls themselves were pretty good, obviously fresh given the dietary needs of my companions, but the dipping sauce was more reminiscent of a carmel, peanut sauce hybrid... A little runny, but overall decent taste-wise, but not my favorite... Luckily they brought along a little monkeydish of chili sauce that helped us through.

For my entree I ordered Bo Cari Thai, a spicy beef curry with coconut milk & basil sizzling in an iron pot... Not the most Vietnamese of choices, but the name and description sold me. It arrived as advertised, really really hot and still bubbling within the cast iron cauldron. The fragrance was killer, just what you'd hope it would smell like. First taste was very positive, well seasoned, great aromatics and a rich coconut broth. Beef was tender and flavorful, and the vegetables seemed to have a French julienne, which, given the name of the restaurant and Vietnamese food's history, made me happy. 

For desert, one friend banana with coconut ice cream, and another fried banana with a Grand Marnier flambé... Again with the French touchés (get it?). The regular fried banana and coco ice cream arrived as advertised, but the flambé banana arrived next... The waiter quickly doused with booze, and set about to flambé right at the table. Took a little while, but he did well by it. I appreciated this little demonstration, as you don't see it much these days. Flavor-wise both were enjoyable, and pretty much how you'd expect them to taste. Nothing more, nothing less.

Bill came to $100 for three entrees, one beer, one bottle of wine, two desserts, and one appetizer. Not bad at all. 

Summary? Well, Aux Delices will probably see me again... It wasn't overwhelmingly great, but had some moments of greatness and also a few of mediocrity. I am curious to explore the menu a bit more after seeing some other reviews, and will update this review accordingly (if need be).  

In general; solid food, good service, reasonable prices. 

Enjoy :)
author: Will S.

description:
Service consistently awkward/ bad , food consistently good . Just be in good company for the good food !! 

Ps .... The water refilling  , you'll see what I mean .
author: Lauren S.

description: worst service ever for togo customer. The asian woman? idk. but anyways, she was being rude. I understand that you may are busy, but I also worked at the restaurant before so I understand the feeling when the restaurant gets so busy. HOWEVER, her attitude made me felt that I donnot want to go there anymore. Seriously, what was wrong with you?
author: Erica Y.

description:
I came here here expecting to be blown away. Although the food was solidly good in a nice atmosphere, I expected a bit more. I would come back and try out some of the more french style dishes instead of just having pork/shrimp skewers and basil chicken.

Overall, this is a very comfortable upscale french vietnamese restaurant. Certainly it is more expensive than your usual pho restaurant.
author: Tricia K.

description:
Awesome Vietnamese food.  Everything was delicious, but I particularly loved the garlic noodles and crispy chicken.  I'm definitely going back soon to eat again.

Parking is bad around here, so I recommend taking a taxi/Uber/Lyft/etc.
author: Matt N.

description: A favorite for those cold, foggy SF nights when you need something like warm pho to tide you over.  Super consistent, great quality pho and other traditional Vietnamese dishes.  Bonus - Loving Cup is right across the street so makes for a great dinner + dessert combo.
author: Morgan C.

description:
My top 1 vietnamese restaurant in SF... Said by a vietnamese native who grew up with his mother's fantastic vietnamese cuisine.

Great choice
Fresh ingredients
Exquisite taste
Great service
Nice restaurant layout, perfect for couples or groups of 4-5
Great price/value, given all the above

My only regret is not having checked the dessert carte. 
Will do in the very near future, can't wait.
author: Itachi U.

description:
Solid food---plain and simple

My daughter and I were looking for some good food. Being St. Patrick's day, every place was packed. We figured we'd give this place a try. 

REALLY glad we did. I urge you try #50 on menu---filets of beef in yummy sauce. Its probably the most expensive dish on menu---but it did not disappoint.  Garlic noodles---good---could have had more flavor---but solid. We got a chicken dish too---fried in a yummy spicy sauce----was really good to dip the noodles in---loved that sauce with the chicken. That and brown rice and it all added up to a great meal---for a reasonable price.

Our waiter seemed a bit detached---but it was packed so we'll give that a pass.

Anyway---as for local food---its really good.
author: Chris O.

description:
This is a great spot.  My wife says that it's her favorite asian spot...and she's asian!

We ordered delivery and had the salt and pepper prawns, crab fried rice, and imperial rolls. All very good so I am assuming the pho is great.  The food could have been spicier but it is a place we will order from again.
author: Jeremy E.

description: This is my go to place for delivery. The imperial rolls and crispy spicy garlic chicken with brown rice is my go to. The garlic noodles are also delicious. The portions are huge, I always get at least two meals out of it. I've never been to the restaurant itself so can't speak for that but it's great delivery and it's fast!
author: Lizzy U.

description:
Full disclosure: I'm basing this entirely on one visit, and one dish. Following the advice of many other visitors, I ordered the garlic noodles here. For $9.25, I received about a pint of noodles, with some basil and scallions on top. The noodles were bland and had a vague hint of garlic. This was basically a side dish, and a flavorless one, at that. For the price of a full entree, I got a miserable dinner. Honestly, just plain noodles with a handful of scallions and a few scattered pieces of garlic? Not even any salt?!

Maybe the other dishes are better. Maybe the chef had an off night. Maybe - but for getting ripped off this badly, I have no desire to find out.
author: Matthew L.

description:
I came here during my lunch break. I wasn't sure what to expect. I thought it might have been like the Lemongrass across the street except Vietnamese instead of Thai. I didn't like Lemongrass but I thought I'll give Aux Delices a try. 

When my friend and I walked in there was a big party I believe on their lunch break and these two professionals at separate tables on their break too. We were seated by these two people. I felt it was very close quarters and they could have listened in on our conversations if they chose to.  - star

I definitely didn't want to have pho because I felt it would be really small portions. I ordered the bun bo xao. My friend ordered some fried chicken thing with rice. It looked like something from panda express. ew. Mine looked like your regular bun but without the sauce off to the side. I enjoyed mine thoroughly except I could have gotten more at my regular pho joint. 

What made this experience different from other Viet restaurants was the complementary congee. It was SO good. I want to come back and just have congee and probably something else since that isn't filling. After reading other reviews I would definitely like to try the less traditional viet dishes they offer like the papaya salad and desserts. Probably try some rolls too since it was mentioned in a lot of reviews.

Two bathrooms. They weren't labeled women or men. You can use either. Very clean and spacious.

They offer cozy booths with pillow arm rests. I wish I got to sit in those booths. =[
author: Sarah C.

description:
I love this place, the ambiance is nice, good lighting and decor, not like most Asian restaurants that have that bright fluorescent light and sticky tables. I went here for a date and apparently this place is where my date always ordered his dinner from (the same 2 dishes! That's a problem lol).

We ordered the Banh Xeo for an appetizer. I never try the Vietnamese crepe in the past and felt so missed out. It's so good, crispy, and tastes fresh with the bean sprouts and the sweet vinegar sauce. The Ga Kho is also really good, can't go wrong with caramelized chicken in a hot pot.

Definitely will come back and try other dishes!
author: Novalina N.

description:
Excellent Vietnamese cuisine in the Russian Hill neighborhood! Some friends had mentioned this place, the glass noodles in particular, so of course I had to try it when I discovered it was a 4-star rated place on Yelp! A cold, wet rainy day seemed like the perfect opportunity to eat some noodles.

I ordered the vegetable glass noodles with garlic and ginger. Not being a ginger fan, I fully expected to pick out the ginger pieces, yet surprisingly didn't have to. The ginger slices were well-cooked and lacking the usual potency, so perfecto for me!

Overall, the noodle dish was quite light, lacked oiliness, and was piled high with fresh vegetables (mushrooms, onions, garlic, ginger, celery, broccoli, and carrots) that were cooked perfectly al dente.
