Server gave off major vibes that she didn't want to be there.  I understand, I don't wanna be at work sometimes too, but I never made a customer feel it uncomfortable about it.  Maybe it was cuz we were the first table.  But still, no excuse.
author: Kat K.

description:
This place is a little pricey, but the miles I get for dining here (yay UA Mileage Plus Dining) and the really tasty food keeps me going back for more.

(Not that I've ever actually been there before, they deliver!)

The clay pot chicken with caramel sauce is hands down the best dish at this restaurant. The chicken is so tender and the sauce is the perfect combination of sweet and savory. Delicious over rice or by itself, this is my go-to dish when I'm in the mood for superb Vietnamese food.
author: Cynthia T.

description:
I went into this place with my parents for lunch, expecting it to be really good Vietnamese food based off of the reviews, but it was sub-par.  

The Good: We ordered the appetizer sampler and the Vietnamese crepe. These were decent.  Very flavorful, fresh, and well-made.

The restaurant was clean and had a good atmosphere.   

The Bad:  Our waitress kept on asking us if we knew how to eat the appetizers.  We told her yes every time she asked us.  My parents grew up in Laos and Thai Land.  They have ate Thai, Vietnamese, and Laotian food all of their lives. The waitress made a comment on how we were eating the crepe, "That's how you guys eat that?"  My mom was simply cutting the crepe into pieces with the knives provided on the dish so that we could each take a piece of the crepe.  Bad form on the part of the waitress.

The main food is what I didn't care for.  Mainly because I was expecting something that tasted more "Vietnamese".  What I got looked like a Vietnamese dish, but it tasted more like a Chinese dish. My parents and I all agreed on this.      

Conclusion:  Go here for the appetizers, but not for the food.  You won't get authentic tasting Vietnamese food here. The waitress we got definitely didn't help our experience.
author: Meng V.

description:
We eat here since we came to San Francisco and we bring every friend and family who visits. The owners are a very nice and fun family and their stuff is great. This is a cosy place to eat and every day. We brought groups up to 20 people and no one ever complained. The food is great, the staff is nice and the prices are very affordable - couldn't live without them.
Tip: Their chicken rice porridge saved me from a couple of colds!
author: Patrick E.

description:
I used to live around the corner from this place and became obsessed with Aux Delices.  My wife and I would order 2-3 times/week for a while.  We tried pretty much everything on the menu and never really found anything we didn't like. 

There were some things we liked a lot though.  The clay pot chicken with caramel sauce was great, but our favorite was the barbecue beef skewers.  Really excellent.

I thought the decor inside the restaurant could use a makeover though.  They have aspirations to being a fancy wine bar, but come off more like a fancy Denny's.
author: Bob R.

description:
Had heard about this place from foodie friends so we thought to give it a try. Parking is terrible, which made us late for our rez. Called to let them know, and walked in to find 4 tables full. We were taken to what has to be the worst table in the place, next to stacks of linens unhidden from view. Not a nice 2-top at all, but hey, it's their restaurant and it can look how they want it to.
Nice, extensive menu, good variety of meats and vegs, and what came out of the kitchen was very nice, to be sure, but I'm not so sure the experience was worth $80 for two. Having white tablecloths does not ensure a comiserate experience, and there are many less pricey places to enjoy the cuisine of Vietnam. If you're looking to spend many bucks for a nice meal, this place is for you.
author: William M.

description: The beef pho (pho bo?), shaking beef (bo luc lac) and garlic noodles were all good.  The three of us shared and we each got our own Thai tea (in a Vietnamese restaurant... but so what?).  This was a really good shaking beef... not as tough as Bodega Bistro and not as oyster-sauce flavored as Jasmine Garden.  I'd come back if I was in the area.
author: Erika C.

description:
this is kind of a "MEH" "Americanized" Vietnamese restaurant..the restaurant is very cute though and seems to run by most Vietnamese people, however I think that I have had better Vietnamese food at some "hole-in-a-wall" Vietnamese places...we ordered Vegetarian Sweet and Sour soup, the soup was actually pretty good, however, in Vietnam we generally eat soup with the meal, it's not as an "appetizer" like American cuisine, usually in Vietnam during a meal, we have 3 kinds of dishes, one soup, one vegetable and one meat, and we eat everything together, so the set up of soup as an appetizer here is kind of weird to me already since after eating a big bowl of soup, I am kind of full and not really thrilled for other dishes...However, the soup was good, so I was looking towards to the main dishes. 

We ordered simmered caramelized catfish in the clay pot, this is a traditional Vietnamese dish, I myself know how to make this and made it many times for my boyfriend. However, I must say this dish is disappointing, the catfish is burned, sticky to the bottom of the clay pot, the caramelized sauce is too sweet for my liking, and there is no "kick" to it, I mean you have to add a little red pepper flakes and pepper to give this dish an interesting flavor. My Indian boyfriend actually loved this dish when he tried it one time at another restaurant, so we have been ordering it at Vietnamese restaurants when we go out, but even he said that this is too weird for him and it made him not like caramelized catfish dish anymore, since it's weird that he thinks catfish was drenched in a sweet caramelized sauce...

Second dish was even a bigger let-down...we ordered chicken with ginger and lemongrass..this is not even authentic Vietnamese dish, it tasted like Chinese (per my Indian bf, and I agreed with him) the sauce was again too sweet, and also it's watery, the onion was not sauteed well, it tasted just like boring boneless chicken pieces  dipped diluted, watery hoisin sauce...I thought it was the simmered chicken that sauteed with lemongrass and ginger like my mom used to make...anyway this dish is not good at all..

I would have to say that their service is really good though, their servers actually were friendly and I saw that the servers were talking to customers just like chit chatting so it seems that they do have long term customers, but honestly this place is an Americanized, kind of pretentious Vietnamese restaurant that I would not go again...I mean I would love to go back since it's a cute place, but the food is a complete let down and so I guess it will not be worth it..
author: Quyen N.

description:
family runned: . .. nice setting . .. at this time, more like 3.5 . ..

+ : friendly service . .. cute dinner wares . .. Banh Xeo or Vietnamese crepes - not bad at all - crisp and not too oily at the bottom . .. Sample Platter was okay, the Banh Cuon or Vietnamese steamed dumplings were the best especially with some sauce over - lol - mM . .. Ga Chua Ngot or crispy chicken in "sticky" sauce was good, a bit on the dry side . .. Bo Xao Toi or beef sauteed was nice and tender . .. And ! !! * YAYY * * for having brown rice on the menu . .. also, wine selection that is not on the menu . .. ;)

-- : street parking, esp. on a Saturday night :( . .. Vietnamese herbs or rau was on the bare minimal side - couple of lettuce, cilantro and mint only - where are all the other yummy herbs? . .. dishes were hit and miss . ..
author: Y I L I W.

description:
There wasn't one dish I want to tell the world about, but everything we had was very, very good. The chicken in caramel sauce clay pot was smaller than expected, but ended up being a satisfying amount of delicious chicken. The pork and shrimp skewers were barbecued to perfection, and the tofu, veggie and noodle dish was a splendid combination of each ingredient. This one might be my favorite.

Go expecting friendly service, reasonable prices and an abundance of dishes you can't go wrong with.
author: Jason B.

description:
The best & most quiet Viet restaurant in SF! 

The pricing is slightly higher than most viet restaurants in the city. 
However, the food quality, service, and ambiance is worth it! 

Their Pho is the most flavorful and least MSG tasting in the city. 

I recommend to enjoy food there, rather than takeout / delivery.
author: Brian H.

description: On the hunt for the best pho in SF...this is the 3rd place we have tried & my fav so far. Before the main event we had the imperial rolls to start & they were yummy. I can be a disaster with chopsticks, it's like I have 2 left hands sometimes but I noticed other guests using their fingers & in that moment the chopsticks were left behind. Now for the beef pho...it was delicious, the beef was tender & the broth was the best so far but the hunt will continue.
author: Sorcha Sin R.

description: I rarely complain about mundane business ethics in such a forum, but I have to put this out there. I live exactly one mile from this place. They will only deliver within a .5 mile radius?? When I called to inquire about this, they said they would deliver to me but only if it's a $25 minimum which doesn't include a mandatory 10% gratuity. Can I also add that I live on the exact same street in North Beach?? A-VOID!
author: James P.

description:
Although no one can touch my grandma's cooking, they sure do come close!

My boyfriend's family has been coming here for years, so they are very well acquainted with the owners and their daughter. They are so nice and freindly. The wife always makes it a point to ask me in Vietnames how I'm doing. (:

We usually start with the Canh Chua (spicy lemon grass soup) and then order a bunch of things to share. My favorites are the imperial rolls and crispy garlic chicken things (Ga Chien?). They even have the little slow drip Vietnamese coffee maker that you put on top of your cup! That's pretty authentic.
author: Jeanette P.

description:
I've been to Aux Delices a few times over the years and eachtime I leave belly full and happy. Whether it's the garlic noodles, fresh spring rolls or shaken filet mignon cubes (mmm!), everything comes out with some family TLC. Mint, cilantro, basil, lemongrass, it's all here.

Their original location opened in 1975 on Potrero Avenue (http://www.yelp.com/biz/new-aux-delices-vietnamese-restaurant-san-francisco), and this location came around 1987, which is still very old by restaurant years. Goes to show that the Nguyen family is doing something right! 

When last there, I asked about the name, and it translates as 'At The Delights' which I think somehow manages to capture this quaint, neighborhood Vietnamese eatery just fine.
author: Nish N.

description:
Went there last week and really enjoyed the food. However, there was a long wait and the service wasn't all the good.

I ordered the ginger & lemongrass chicken which was delicious! The vegetarian spring rolls were also good. My date had the curry and really enjoyed it.

We didn't order dessert but next time I go I'm definitely ordering the fried banana (and making a reservation!)
author: Jeanette L.

description:
Sampler Platter
Garlic Noodles
Ga Chien - or sticky chicken is what i call it
Caramel Salmon 
Fresh Lemonade 

this has been my go to menu at this restaurant since i started coming here.  depending on how hungry/how many people i'm with, will depend on the combo of choices i get.  mmm.. wish i had some of that for lunch today..
author: Joyce W.

description:
Let me preface this with the fact that I think service can make or break a restaurant, but I have not actually eaten at the restaurant in this case just ordered delivery.

It may be a little pricey, but I really like this food and being super picky I will pay more for better quality!  The sticky/crispy chicken is really good as are the garlic noodles and shrimp chow mein.  Pass on the Imperial Rolls as they are not worth the money or calories.  The shaking beef is excellent though and I can't wait to try more!  

I'm a SUPER picky eater and I really like this place's food!  I've only reviewed a few places, and I don't like how Yelp does this rating system as there should be a separate rating for food vs. service (see my da Flora review) and one or the other can ruin or make an experience!  I have a very good feeling that there is a lot of bad service in SF and when people get service they feel like writing a review about it and giving the places more credit than they should as the really good places do get cheated a lot I've noticed in the rating systems.
author: Laura D.

description: Have only had delivery but always delicious, fast and piping hot. Imperial rolls, garlic noodles, crispy chicken, and beef with lemongrass are my favourite.  Incredibly tasty!
author: Oona C.

description:
You will notice throughout my reviews that there are 2 constants...beer and food. You don't see me reviewing gyms do you? Well, case in point - this quaint restaurant is 2 blocks from my apartment and I still order delivery. Spring rolls can get heavy walking up 6 flights of stairs. 

I'm border line obesessed with their fresh spring rolls & peanut sauce. Although not to be outdone by their mouth watering garlic noodles and carmel pots. 

When I can muster up the energy to dine in, I'm always pleasantly surprised by the romantic atmosphere. Once I stopped in here with my dining companion who is allergic to gluten. The waitor was beyond accomodating and spent a long time going over the gluten free dishes. I was impressed with the service and will continue to come back here...or order delivery.
author: Megan C.

description:
This place is awesome! The food is authentic and there are several vegetarian options for my friends. I called to see if they could seat a party of 14 and it was easy-peasy. They emailed me a few sample menus in advanced, since it's better to have a set menu with such a large group to ensure the food arrives at the same time. 

We ordered:

+ banh xeo, vegetarian and non vegetarian (a personal favorite)
+ sample platter 
+ steak sewer marinated in lemongrass
+ garlic noodles (simple but great if you love garlic)
+ crispy chicken in sticky garlic sauce (highly recommended)
+ caramel salmon (was ok)
+ veggies and tofu
+ jasmine rice

Would definitely come back next time I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Phuong M.

description: Very good choice cuts of meats, we had both chicken and beef. The sauces were tasty and everything was delicious. This place is amazing. I can't believe how inexpensive it is for such a high end taste and atmosphere. I am addicted!
author: Michelle F.

description: Late night dinner, last minute on the way home. They were quick and friendly. The food was fine, but nothing special. They closed at 10, but continued to seat people anyway. Good for a last minute dinner if there is nothing else convenient.
author: Carlynn A.

description:
It would have been given 4 stars but the service is extremely slow getting order and the food. It took 15 mins to get someone to take our order.
It was fast when we asked for the bill.
Very good food, I would go back, You need to go with a group of 4 because we got a great variety.
Hope the owners read this.... faster service please
author: Alison W.

description: 2 blocks away from my house. Needed some warm Pho on a breezy night. Hit the spot and I'll come back again but not worth driving here from other neighborhoods.
author: Inna L.

description:
3 stars is a good thing - don't hate!

The food here is pretty tasty, but is it that much better than the hole-in-the-wall Vietnamese places that it warrants the noticeable price increase?  Probably not.  The jacked up prices reflect the nicer dining room, prettier presentation, more utensils, and better service as compared to the aforementioned hole-in-the-walls.  Am I willing to pay the increase?  Yes, when I want good Vietnamese food and feel completely relaxed and taken care of (but see note below). The place also seems popular with the pick-up orders as evidenced by the constant stream of people ducking in to retrieve their food.

Note:  Minus stars for taking away my extra plate and utensils (even chopsticks) when I was clearly sharing food, and only leaving my bowl of pho and the soup spoon.  Who eats pho with only a spoon!?
author: Vicente G.

description: This place is great. The food is fresh, tasty and varied. There are a lot of good options (#30 is my favorite), especially the pho, noodles and chicken. It's a pleasant environment to eat and they take reservations, even last-minute, which is convenient. Try it out!
author: Julia S.

description:
If you're craving Slanted Door but aren't near the Ferry Building and want to save a few bucks, come here.

My friend and I devoured the following:

PHO - BEEF or CHICKEN NOODLE Slices of beef or chicken with rice noodles in a traditional beef broth
- I'm not a Pho fan but I had a few bites and though the flavors were nice and clean. I would actually order a bowl on my own. Don't dawdle- it tastes best when immediately served. 

***CHA GIO - IMPERIAL ROLLS (FRIED) Fried rolls with pork, chicken, bean thread noodles, mushrooms & vegetables
- Mmm, mmm good. Ladies, don't let the word "fried" scare you. This is well worth the calories.

**GA CHIEN Crispy chicken sautéed in a sweet, spicy, garlic sticky sauce
- See comments above.

MIEN XAO RAU Glass noodles sautéed with vegetables in a garlic & ginger sauce
- Similar to the glass noodles @ Slanted Door sans crab but still good.
author: Christina C.

description:
Decor is halfway between Slanted Door and your typical hole-in-the-wall Vietnamese place.  Service was unfortunately on the surly side.  
Imperial rolls were the best part of the meal.  Pho was only so-so ... had better elsewhere.  

This might be a good choice though, if you are meeting someone for something work-related and you REALLY feel like Vietnamese, if you're opposed to Slanted Door.
author: Jaina S.

description: I ordered this online before I left my desk at work, and it arrived very shortly after I got home, hot and fresh! The hubby got brown rice ($2) with Ga Chua Ngot (crispy chicken with sticky sweet sauce, $11) and I got the Muc Cari hay Xao (calamari with garlic broth and veggies, $11). Mine was very good, but his was better. We will definitely do this again!
author: Emily S.

description:
This is a review by a vegetarian

I'll have to remember this place the next time someone wants to go to La Folie.  I can eat here before or after the show-meal.

Usually tofu dishes are either bland or spicy-delicious. This place has a tasty lemongrass/ginger dish that makes tofu taste good without having to creep up the Scovile scale.
author: Bob R.

description:
This is one of those places you like to have nearby. It has something for everyone and the food feels homey, definitely the kind of place you go to on a rainy tuesday. 

If you're looking for good (but not spectacular), reasonably priced food this is a great choice. They have everything you'd want on the menu from the healthy (salads, grilled chicken, etc.) to the fried.
author: Megan B.

description: Service was a little slow, but polite. Garlic noodles pretty tasty. Beef Satay flavorful but not a fan of the noodles that they come with. Overall, I'd come back only if I was in the area...
author: Briene S.

description:
After shopping with the girls, it always best to end the evening with great food.  Luckily, we found this place and they let us in so close to closing.   
We jumped right into entree and ordered 4 dishes for 4 girls and it totally hit the spot.  Great balance of tasty food and good portions for a good price :D  My favorite was #61 - Mein Xao Cua - glass noodle with seafood.  Second favorite was #16b - garlic noodles.
author: Karena L.

description:
We made reservations for four for a Saturday night (got seated right away). It was full, but not crazy packed, which was nice since it wasn't too loud or hectic. The menu is pretty extensive too. Something for everyone. 

- Thai iced tea: One of the better places I've had this at! 
- Garlic noodles: We shared this. Glad we did since for what it was I thought it was a bit overpriced. Not that it wasn't good, but I wouldn't have been satisfied having this alone. It was a nice compliment to the other dishes though!
- Mien Xao Cua: They give you a hefty portion, which is nice. But nothing stellar. Even though compared to the garlic noodles this dish is more complex, I'd rather order that than this. 
- Bo Xao Toi: Usually I'm not a huge fan of beef, but this was delicious! Especially with the sauce they give you on the side. (I mean, you can't really go wrong with garlic and onions). Plus they give you a good amount of veggies too. 
- Ga Chua Ngot/Crispy Chicken: The star of the night! We had to order this since most of the reviews seemed to recommend it. It was perfectly crispy and cooked very well. We even contemplated ordering seconds of this...THAT GOOD. A must try if you're coming here.

And we were really, really excited to try the coconut crème brûlée with passion fruit sorbet but unfortunately they had run out. :( They were nice about it though and our waitress even recommended a place nearby if we were craving dessert. Definitely will come back to try it eventually!
author: Jenny C.

description:
Well. I have wanted to try this restaurant for about a month now and finally got the opportunity. I had to order our food to go which should make no difference. It was a Wednesday just before 1pm. When I walked in their where only 3 tables occupied, that gave me an instant feeling on how my lunch might be.

I ordered the garlic noodles, imperial rolls, chicken with garlic and lemon grass sauce and brown rice. Less than 5 minutes later three of us where eating, food stayed hot but that was the only good thing I can say about it.

We really looked at the reviews on yelp and thought it would be good, well all three of us did not care for any of the dishes ordered. Not only that, I felt the prices where a bit on the high side for the amount of food we got.

I hope this helps others decide to maybe try another Vietnamese Restaurant in the city, we all know their are many. lunch time with only a total of customers is never a good sign.

So sorry but, I hate spending money on bad food.
author: susan g.

description:
This is, hands down, the best Vietnamese food I've had in the city. I've had my fair share of disappointing green papaya salads and cha gio, but this was good home cookin'. 

It's comparable in quality (though maybe a little more pricey) than the authentic vietnamese restaurants in San Jose. Not every dish is the *best*, but all are very good - I find that to be the true challenge at most vietnamese restaurants.

I will say that I wouldn't recommend the Pho as the best - it's a bit too beefy for my taste and there are other places in the city where it's more of a specialized dish. What I ate and would recommend are:
- Canh Chua (tamarind sour soup with tomato, pineapple, and prawns) was excellent.  The perfect amount of spicy and the right balance of sweet and sour.
- Banh Xeo to be authentic (I'd recommend asking for extra lettuce to wrap it in, it's a large portion and wrapping it in lettuce cuts some of the fried grease). 
- Ca Kho To (braised catfish in a claypot with a savory sweet caramel sauce). This is one of my favorite dishes and I'm so happy to find a pretty good version available in the city. It's a little on the heavy side, but as long as you have plenty of rice to sop up the sauce you'll be very happy
- Green Papaya Salad with Calamari. The calamari is sliced into slivers almost as thin as the papaya which actually makes the whole thing more enjoyable. Good balance of sweet and sour. 

The fried banana and coconut ice cream was a hit at my table. I personally enjoyed the mango sorbet (it tasted like biting into a mango!). 

It's also a good value. Overall we were quite stuffed and (3 of us) ended up paying about $27/pp with tax and tip. Between us we ordered 7 dishes.

I'll definitely be coming back here frequently!
author: dana n.

description:
I really like the neighborhood feel to this restaurant, which is a little cheaper than other French Vietnamese options in SF (also never has a wait).  

I really like the cellophane noodles with crab and shrimp and my ultimate favorite is the claypot of caramelized shrimp and pork (the sauce is amazing!).  I also like the papaya salad (reminds me of Thailand!) and the imperial rolls.
author: Marisa G.

description:
Aux Delices is one of our favorite Vietnamese delivery places in the city. We are huge fans of Asian food, and in particular, Asian restaurants that aren't loaded with MSG and filled with "meat gum". 

The food at Aux Delices is very fresh, and there is very little fat or grizzle on their meat. The only cons are that there prices are kind of high and their delivery times are typically 45 minutes to an hour. Not a huge deal - we are willing to pay more and wait for good food. 

Recommendations: 
- spring rolls 
- shrimp or chicken chow mein 
- Ga Chien 
- Green salad 
- Fried banana
author: Anne Marie F.

description: This place is great for take-out/delivery, but not the most appealing atmosphere for dine in. Order the caramel chicken, garlic noodles, imperial rolls and spring rolls. You won't be sorry!
author: Jessica N.

description: The vegetable spring rolls and Do Bien Xao, among other things, were quite good; the atmosphere was casually elegant; the service was a bit slow, but they were polite and kept our water glasses filled. For the moderate price it's certainly worth visiting repeatedly. Also offered complimentary valet parking (which we didn't use).
author: Christopher A.

description:
Imperial Rolls
Medium Chicken Pho

delicious!
author: Manlio L.

description: My go to spot in the Marina for Vietnamese. Although Sweet Aroma has cheaper deals if you're looking to save a little money
author: Kim H.

description:
Love, love, love this place. 

Super fun shrimp and sugar cane appetizer (which are rolls delivered to you disassembled - you get to soften the skins in a bowl of hot water and then pair them with noodles, carrots, etcetera), superb chicken and rice porridge, ethereal garlic noodles, amazing chicken claypot, and fantastic spicy basil chicken.

A very relaxed atmosphere, never too much trouble to get a table, and some of the speediest delivery in Russian Hill. Such an epic win.
author: Carla C.

description:
I get take-out of the clay pot chicken with carmel sauce more often than I'd like to admit. It's delish and can hit the spot after a long day at work. Their take out portions aren't quite big enough to last for 2 meals, but aren't quite small enough to keep me from being stuffed when I try to eat it all because it is so good. 

If you are in the neighborhood and want something chill, not expensive with no wait, stop in. They have a $10 bottle of nigori sake that I think is a great deal if you dine-in.
author: Katie W.

description:
I love Vietnamese. I'm a big believer in a spicy bowl of Pho curing any cold. That being said, Aux Delices is super tasty. It feels like the local asian restaurant your parents took you to when you were little. I'm crazy about clay pot anything, and their clay pot chicken is as good as any. 
I'm a little suspicious that they use MSG, but I don't want to point fingers unless I know for sure... so for now, yum!
author: Kenzie P.

description:
The food is ok.  We tried a bunch of things of which the only thing I really liked were the garlic noodles because they had a strong savory garlic flavor and a good texture.  Other than that, I found everything a tad too oily.  The caramel salmon had a very strong sauce that couldn't entirely mask the fishiness of the not-too-fresh fish.  The beef was pretty tender but entirely forgettable.  Lemongrass tofu had a good flavor but too much oil.  Crispy chicken tasted like a fresher and mildly better version of Panda Express.

By far the weirdest event that happened at Aux Delices involved one of our waiters.  My friend ordered an ice tea that came with unlimited refills.  Halfway through the meal, our waiter brought over another ice tea - we assumed it was for my friend since she was almost done with her first glass.  She took a sip from the second one.  Ten minutes later, the waiter appeared and asked for her ice tea back.  Confused, she handed it back to him, after which he went back to the bar, added two slices of lemon, and trotted it to the table next to us!  Apparently, they had also ordered an ice tea and the one the waiter brought us was meant for them.

Honestly, I understand that sometimes things get brought to the wrong table and I'm more than willing to give it back.  However, shouldn't the waiter realize his mistake within a few minutes?  If it's something like iced tea that costs approximately 3 cents to make, shouldn't he just have poured a fresh one for the table next to us?

We got out of there before they could swipe a half-eaten dessert from another table and give it to us.
author: Sonia C.

description:
Love it . Aux Delices is one of my go-to week night delivery spots. The sauces are always dead on and everything is really fresh. Favorites of mine include the white fish with dill and sake sauce, Chao Ga (any of the soups) or the squid and scallops with ginger garlic sauce. The imperial rolls are also quite good and have a nice crispness without being greasy.

My one qualm is that many of the dishes could use more vegetables, but I chalk that up to the style of French Vietnamese cuisine. It's also not the cheapest way to go, but I've never once been disappointed with my food. I will desperately miss this place if I ever move.
author: Leah Y.

description:
Another awesome asian restaurant close-by for take-out - SCORE!

I was thrilled to discover Benjarong Thai for my take-out cravings, and now I can add Aux Delices Vietnamese to the list! :)

Last night a few girlfriends and I ordered take-out & watched the "Sex & the City movie" while drinking wine - the perfect relaxing evening. 

Both of them had raved about this appetizer, and I too, LOVED it:

#13 BANH CUON - VIETNAMESE STEAMED DUMPLING Steamed rice flour filled with ground pork & mushrooms served with fish sauce

I ordered #32 CAI XANH XAO: "Broccoli sautéed with ginger & garlic and beef" for my entree, and while it was good, I look forward to trying something else next time.

I highly recommend this place for take-out, as our hostess raves about this place, and everything she's eaten here, including their pho!
author: Sally M.

description: Stopped in per the high ratings on Yelp. We started with pho tai, Imperial rolls and shared bun thit nuong. It was only the pho tai that missed the mark. It's not that it was bad, I just prefer the more flavor stock and fixings I get a local shop near home. Overall, very fresh and tasty.
author: Kellee K.

description:
I still cannot pronounce the name of this restaurant. It claims it is a French-Vietnamese restaurant. I think it includes some other cultural influences on some of their dishes.

Called in for reservations for a party of 10 for dinner. They scheduled us in for 6pm. They weren't that busy when we came in on Saturday. They encourage having a "fix menu" for dinner for parties of 10 and larger. Meaning you choose 2 appetizers and 2-3 entrees for your party and they make 2.5 servings of each dish. It comes out faster for the group and makes it easier on the restaurant because they don't have to individually make 10 different dishes. I understand the restaurant's request, but 2-3 entrees for my group was not enough and we ended up ordering 2 more single dishes. So you can take a look at the menu online their website. I know it says 2006 menu, but it's basically the same but prices have changed. They encourage to place the order prior to coming to the restaurant for the group to expedite the food - but honestly, the food comes out really fast anyway.

I didn't get to see their wine list but my friend ordered two white wines to complement the dinner and they were perfect! I ordered for the group: spicy papaya salad, spring rolls, shaking beef, catfish in clay pot, stir fry vegetables, some chicken and calamari curry. The papaya salad is very spicy! The spring rolls were OK - I've had much better. The catfish and shaking beef were delicious!!! I did not care for the stir fry vegetables, chicken dish or calamari curry. I don't recommend them; plus they weren't a typical "vietnamese dish".

The iced coffee is strong here and very good. The fried banana and ice cream is delicious here!! Definitely save some room for dessert.

Parking around here is a major pain. It took us 20 minutes to find parking. The restaurant does offer $10 parking. Where do they park your car? I have no idea.
author: Melissa T.

description: Heavy-handed cooking, salty food with surly, impatient wait-staff. Very disappointed. Might have been good at some time, but it's no more than poor Chinese cooking trying to be something it's not. Don't waste your time or money.
author: Robert E.

description:
We were wandering down Polk Street to find a yummy place to try...while we were reading the menu of Aux Delices a random elderly gentleman walking pass offered us his unsolicited 2 cents... 'eat here, it has fabulous seafood.  the place across the street also has great seafood, but since you're here...try it, you won't regret it.'

Well how can one not take a recommendation like that! Plus I was really craving seafood.  We had:

Starter:  Sampler platter...pretty darn good imperial rolls

Entrees:  Mixed Seafood with Vegetables (I think it was #57) - yummy lots of veggies, but not enough seafood and it was a bit too saucy for me.  But that aside the dish is still tasty and we'd order it again

Catfish in Claypot (I think it is #64):  YUM YUM YUMMY!!!  I love catfish, I love catfish in claypot.  I even dare to say this is even tastier than The Slanted Door version....and THAT is sayin alog since The Slanted Door is really one of my ALL TIME favorite restaurant.  The dish had just the right amount of carmelized sauce and spices...oh I didn't want to share this dish, but seeing how we were there for a celebration I had to share....but next time I ain't sharing!

Dessert:  Fried Bananas and Vanilla Ice Cream.  I'm not typically a Fried Banana dessert fan...I think I overdosed on it as a kid...so I don't tend to order this, but wow I was pleasantly surprised by how much I LOVED it.  It had just enough batter on the banana to be tasty and not overwhelmed (you know what I  mean...sometimes it seems like you're just eating the batter and no bananas!)...

It ain't cheap.  Cheaper than The Slanted Door but not cheap like going to the Loin for Vietnamese food...but I'd go back fo sho!!
author: Mao K.

description:
On our way to Thai Spice we spotted this place and gave it a whirl.  It has great decor, the white table linens add a formal elegance. We thought we were under dressed but the hostess assured us we were fine, in fact she said that crunch gym members frequent after a sweaty workout, gross.

Anyways, we ordered wonderful non-fried spring rolls, delicious chicken pho and a crunchy warm vermicelli salad for a whopping $30, where can you get such a well rounded healthy meal at a nice place for that deal?

The wine list looked great so we will be back to try to vino and for great tasting food.
author: Tamz O.

description:
Awesome food, a tad bit on the greasy side at times, but this is definitely one of my go-to neighborhood restaurants.

I've eaten in the restaurant a couple of times, and it's got basic decor and not a whole lot of ambiance, so I generally prefer to get take-out.

I typically get the garlic noodles with some fried tofu and it is fantastic!
author: Erica D.

description:
Terrible Service!!!! Waitress was a complete Bit*h!!!! Should've asked for her name, but she's vietnamese, speaks good english with a bit of vietnamese accent, a little skinny, about 5"3. Super rude, acted like the customers need her instead of providing service to customer.

She said we MUST order everything at once, she won't accept partial orders because she's too busy (this is her exact words). Also, each person MUST order a dish. If you're not ordering, why come to the restaurant (also her exact words).

We ended up leaving the place since she wouldn't accept our orders. I should've asked to talk to her manager, but was so pissed off at her that i couldn't wait to get the hell out of that place.


Update in response to the comment: 
- You didn't check on us several times, not even once. I had to call you to take our order
- We ordered 4 dish, not 3 soups because i said only 1 of us wasn't hungry. I didn't say all of us wasn't hungry.
- Yes it was saturday night at 7pm, but your restaurant was half empty. You were only PRETENDING to be busy.
- If you read my review, i never made the $10 policy a big deal, i didn't even mentioned this policy. Going above $10 is easy, i would have ordered extra appetizers to go above $10 limit IF you had said it politely. IT'S YOUR RUDE WAY OF TALKING THAT PISSED ME OFF.  I did tell you i think it 's a stupid policy, but i never shouted, so stop exaggerating!!!!

I was a waiter too before, i know how it feels to be busy, and i can tell that you WERE NOT BUSY. Just because you were having a bad day, doesn't mean you can treat ur customers anyway u want!!!
author: Boib H.

description: Bland and flavorless pho with no tripe? Over price and tiny portions . Weak
author: Justin A.

description:
An enjoyable experience; the food was nice and it felt versioned for the San Francisco palate.  The food was dependable and yet a very different experience than going to Tu Lan.  The Un Ga Xao Sauteed chicken with with lemongrass was a good way to begin the family style meal I enjoyed.   Next dish was the Ga Chien, a spicy sweet chicken crisped up--nicely tart, sweet, spicy and crunchy.  A table favorite.  The 
Bo Lui Nuong Xa barbeque beef skewers were served nicely warm and accompanied with a tart sour sauce that paired well with the beef. 

The service was a bit challenged and we had to ask several times for our order to be taken.  The restaurant was busy but I didn't think it was overwhelming for service coverage.  I think there was a server shortage the evening I was there. 

The cuisine was good, fresh and meets expectation for the comforting Vietnamese flavor profiles.
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description: Damn, the food here was good. We got the spring rolls, fried rice, and a fish dish (forgot which one). Everything was extremely good. And it's reasonably priced. Will definitely go back.
author: Malvika S.

description: Aux Delice's best days are behind it. Most of their dishes are greasy and oversauced. They used to make great food but just can't execute any more.
author: Bharat V.

description: Carmel salmon. Garlic noodles. Tea. Fried banana ice cream. Over $50 dollars for two people with tax. Too expensive for average food.
author: Zach L.

description:
I really like this place. I used to eat here ALL the time when I worked a little closer to the location but last night I made a special trip because I was CRAVING it. My boyfriend and I were surprised to see a jam-packed restaurant! That's awesome. I always wondered why more people hadn't discovered it - now they clearly have!

We started with the fresh spring rolls. These light, rice paper-wrapped delights are sooooo flippin' good. Just thinking about them now makes me want them for breakfast! With rice noodles, bean sprouts and prawn they are a great way to start any meal. We followed that with the Vietnamese crepe. Oh man is that good. It's deep fried, yes, but the flavors are amazing and you wrap the crispy crepe up in lettuce and add a flavorful fish sauce and it's just plain amazing - the hot crepe and the cold crisp veggies - is to die for.

Then we ordered the pork and prawn clay pot - always a favorite of mine. It's like eating dessert and dinner in one. The sweetness of the sauce over rice is really delicious. And with that we had a more savory item, the lemongrass beef. I completely forgot to order the salt and pepper prawns this time which are also a favorite - but that just gives me a reason to go back sooner.

If you haven't tried this wonderful restaurant - now's the time. Mmm.
author: Carrie S.

description: Really like the food and service here.  Their menu has quite a few dishes you don't get at the typical pho establishments.  I've had the canh chua, goi du du, cha ca, ca kho, and thit nuong.  All the flavors were pretty authentic tasting and flavorful.  The restaurant is very clean and the service by the staff is pretty warm and friendly.  People seem to rave about the mi toi (garlic noodles) which were definitely good, but I'd certainly recommend any of the above items I've had there in the past as I've always been happy with my selections.
author: Kent W.

description:
All you people that never had #50 BO LUC LAC (Shaken filet mignon cubes lightly sauteed with garlic over lettuce) are living an empty and shallow life. 

Don't worry, I was in your shoes up until last night. But then I saw the light and my life was improved by about 6.8 fold.

This thing is amazing. I'm sorry I didn't take a picture of it, but I will next time. It's SUPER tender chunks of filet mignon on a bed of lettuce. I was speechless for a couple of minutes. I literally could not talk. After I came to myself, I actually insisted on silence at the table whenever I would take a bite.

Also, imperial roles=delish, spring rolls=4.5/5 stars. Wines are good and affordable and the service is usually prompt.

In a nutshell, if you run out of Prozac go get some #50 BO LUC LAC from Aux Delices. It will make you VERY VERY happy.
author: Marko J.

description: The crepe dish is pretty good.  The rest of the veggie dishes are pretty weak.  Still better than Lemongrass across the street though.
author: Robby W.

description: Oh yuppie Russian Hill. Food was good, just a little overpriced. Typical Vietnamese food is cheaper and just as delicious over on the East bay. You're paying for ambience and city prices. Not a whole lotta Asians in the crowd, which generally speaks for itself. It's a nice place though and good service. Friendly staff and efficient. Good place to grub when you're in Russian Hill
author: Naomi K.

description:
Cheap?      Yes 
Cheerful?   Not really
Delicious?  Absolutely

Great local neighborhood place.  I really enjoy the food in the much more expensive Vietnamese Le Colonial restaurant, although I now wonder if someone was to blindfold me if I would be able to tell the difference between the food.

Their food and wine menu are both excellent value.  I love their Cha Gio Imperial Rolls, their Ga Chien Crispy chicken and their Bo Luc Lac Filet Mignon is impressive.

In fact....someone pass me the phone.....I need their rolls tonight!
author: Claire m.

description: So good!!!! This place is amazing! Sampler platter is perfect if you want to try different appetizers! Husband had the beef curry, I had the pork and prawns both meats where cooked perfectly with a tasty sauce! We highly recommend coming here.
author: Ashley W.

description:
I love this place because of the following:

1) I can walk to it without going up any hills,
2) they deliver when I don't want to walk at all
3) their service is always very friendly
4) the cubed beef.  

Honorable mention for the fried rice and the prawns.  Eat the shells - that's where all the flavor is.  If you don't eat meat or fish....great, more for me.
author: Priscilla V.

description: A table cloth in a Vietnamese restaurant?  When walking into this place you'll be pleasantly(hopefully) surprised by the pleasant peaceful ambiance and extremely friendly service.  This is a step up from most of the restaurants in the Tenderloin. Food was fresh with juicy cuts of grilled steak perfectly done.  The lunch specials are a good deal. Be sure to get the Imperial rolls, they are delicious, and even though they are not on the lunch special menu, they are worth paying the dinner menu price for.
author: Nosniv X.

description: The caramel chicken and garlic noodles are not to be missed! Still dreaming about them 3 days later. Great neighborhood spot, perfect for a lowkey dinner.
author: Jessica W.

description: I like this Vietnamese restaurant. It's on the more expensive side of Vietnamese places, but not too overpriced. I particularly like their noodle salad and have been taking out from them.
author: X L.

description: I have been walking by this delicious Vietnamese spot for over a year! I love discovering new good eats that are right under my nose. We use them for delivery and they are always within their time estimate. Just an FYI, when they say "spicy" they mean it! Anything they fry is a taste bud sensation. I'm looking forward to exploring more of their menu.
author: Jacqueline S.

description:
favorite vietnamese delivery place. nothing i've tried has been a disappointment. everything is perfectly seasoned, accessorized (herbs and such), and warm when it arrives at my door.

some faves: 
cha ca (fish)
bo luc lac (sauteed beef cubes)
mien ga soup
sauteed veggies (not on the menu but theyll make em)
mien xao rau (glass noodles and veggies)
cha gio (imperial rolls with lettuce wrapper)
thit nuong (pork slices and lettuce wrap)
author: Amy F.

description: Love the garlic noodles, basil chicken and spring rolls.
author: Gordon B.

description:
Í visited Aux Delices when I was living in the city.  I remember 3 things.  The warm inviting atmostphere, kind service and their soup.  Canh Chua a spicy tamarind lemongrass soup with bean sprouts, tomatoes, pineapple & mushrooms.  A lovely blend of fresh vegies and spices just arouse your senses and leave you wanting more.  I had mine with chicken but you can opt for shrimp or vegetarian style.  

And what a catchy na,e?
Aux Delices - what a delightful place to dine.
author: Shiho F.

description: Decent place, the service is a little slow though. If you're into roll-your-own spring rolls, then this is the place to go.
author: Anna J.

description:
I had an epic battle at Aux Delices with my green papaya salad. Chock full of peppers bleeding their delicious spiciness into the crunchy salad, it came full force at my palate. In between wiping the sweat off the top of my head, though, I enjoyed every second of it. The staff helped me battle the fires on my tongue by refilling my water early and often. I left very satisfied by this epic clash of flavor.

My friend had pho, which was very good as well, from the couple of spoonfuls I had, though my papaya fires made it taste a little too hot.

When I go back I'll order a curry to help combat the papaya.
author: Brian B.

description:
My friends and I were excited to have dinner at Aux Delices and it did not disappoint! 

It would get a perfect 5 stars if there weren't so many really really cheap Vietnamese noodles restaurants out there. But still, it wasn't as expensive as we would expect, especially eating at a pretty nice restaurant in San Francisco. 

We shared three dishes and an appetizer:

Fresh rolls: tasted like it was freshly made, and the peanut sauce was REALLY good...not too sweet or too peanutty, just perfect.

Beef pho: really tasty soup and came with the accompanying basil, lime and bean sprouts.

Bun: The rice noodle/salad dish with roast pork and spring roll. That was our favorite. The sauce was minty, fresh and a little sweet. It was beautiful!

Lemongrass tofu: we ordered it without garlic because of an allergy issue but it was STILL just as tasty. I'm really quite impressed how they could make tofu taste so damn good! 

Can't wait to go back to try other dishes!
author: Heather T.

description:
Love Aux Delices. 

A wonderful family run restaurant and my go to spot for four years.

Clay pot chicken
Pho
Bass with dill sauce
garlic noodles 
 
You really can't go wrong with any of their dishes!
author: Kelly B.

description:
Aux Delices is delicious. 
Aux Delices is accomodating for a large party of 16 people.

Aux Delices is good with reservations and was able to keep the price per a person-including drinks below 30 per person, that's with four courses and appetizers. 
Aux Delices made my birthday run smoothly and everyone had a great time. 
Aux Delices is friendly, awesome, and downright rocks. 
I recommend this restaurant. 
Sake shots anybody? Burp.

End of Review. :)
author: J A.

description:
It's been awhile since I've been to a French-influenced Vietnamese restaurant. I wasn't sure what to expect since my friends were really hyped-up over this place. But I'm glad my friends introduced me to Aux Delices (for those who need pronunciation help, "O-Duh-Lease"). 

It's different from other French-Vietnamese restaurants that I've tried. I was afraid the food would be precious as so many SF eateries seem to try to be, but I am glad to be disappointed about it not living up to my prejudging. It is Vietnamese food as I've had and loved at Mom and Pop and fancier restaurants.
author: Jen A.

description:
Imagine food as good as the Slanted Door at half the price.  Yeah, that's what we got last night at Aux Delices.  Ok, you don't get the Ferry Building views but you also don't get the crowds.  Service was friendly although the pacing of our dishes was weird-the entrees came out one at a time, at 3-5 minute intervals.
Four solid stars...if you like Three Seasons, Dragonwell or Lemongrass definitely give Aux Delices a shot.  In my opinion it's the best of the bunch.
author: phil h.

description:
I only gave them 4 stars for so long becuase I dont' know why.  I love everything here so it should be 5 stars.  Why should they get one less star because they aren't Slanted Door but not a regular pho shop.  

For all the vegetarians, this is a secret haven because they have at least 10 purely vegetarian dishes!  

I will type it out for you because it will make you happy.

mixed vegetable soup and tofu in a clear broth
vegetarian spring rolls
crispy crepe filled with bean sprouts, tofu and mushroom served with lettuce to wrap in
fried of fresh tofu sauteed with vegetables and black mushrooms in a garlic and ginger sauce
lemon grass tofu
glass noodles sauteed with vegetables in a garlic and ginger sauce
imitation meat sauteed with vegetable in a garlic soy sauce
vegetable curry
garlic noodles
bun chay

You can also de-meatize all noodle and rice dishes and some other dishes.  I get the broccoli with (choice of chicken, beef) but get it  with tofu or extra broccoli.  It is seasoned with a garlic and ginger sauce.  Its sooooooooo delicate tasting and good.  The carmel sauce that comes in the clay pot is to die for.  I cna just eat this sauce with rice and be content for a few days.
author: Wakako U.

description:
Wanted to take honey's mom and his sister out for a Vietnamese dinner.  Something nice, good food, but wouldn't break the bank.  Difficult to find Vietnamese restaurants that serve a bunch of classic homey dishes.  They're either pho or $5 rice plates joints.  

After reviewing the menu, decided on Aux Delices:

-Goi du du
spicy green shredded papaya with herbs and shrimp.  Quintessential appetizer at any Vietnamese party/get together.  Good.

-Cha gio
fried imperial rolls filled with pork, chicken, bean thread noodles, mushrooms and other veggies.  Done well.

-Heo va tom kho
pork & shrimp caramelized in clay pot.  one of my fave meals growing up and difficult to find at a restaurant.  Very good.

-Cha ca
grilled fillet of fish with dill and green onion served with vermicelli and fresh veggies.  New fave dish since moving to Cali.  They don't serve this at any restaurant in DC.  Usually comes on a sizzling platter and it's enough for two people.  Trying to expand your Vietnamese food repertoire?  Order this this dish if you see it on the menu anywhere.

-Ga xao gung va xa
boneless chicken sauteed with ginger and lemongrass.  Many stir fry Viet dishes are made with ginger and lemongrass.  This was decent, chicken a bit dry.

-Bo luc lac
shaken filet mignon cubes sauteed with garlic over lettuce.  My brother's fave dish.  Hard to mess up if you have good meat and a hot wok.  Very tasty here.

Party of four + above dishes + bottle of wine = little over $100

Extensive Vietnamese menu + better than casual ambiance = Aux Delices
author: Jennifer H.

description:
I grew up with a Vietnamese mother, been to Vietnam and had the real deal there, been to Vietnamese restaurants in hotspots such as Westminster, Ca and San Jose, Ca. I've even experienced the trendy Vietnamese fusion food of the Slanted Door. Basically, I know a thing or two about Vietnamese food. I can confidently say that Aux Delices cooks up the best Vietnamese food I've had in San Francisco. 

The low-down: great prices, great service, wonderful authentic high-quality food, and not at all pretentious. Oh, and we had a reservation and were actually seated promptly despite the line of people waiting there.
author: Kimi W.

description:
I wasn't expecting this place to be so cheap based on its size and the warmth of the decor. For $10, the sample platter we shared was pretty good, especially the Fresh Spring Rolls (mmm, peanut sauce!).

I got a #40, the Ga Hung Que, and while the portion size was perfect (not too big but not so small that I ate it all) it could have used a kick more of basil. Their spicy table sauce is DELICIOUS (if you like really spicy food) and the side of rice was, again, just the right portion size.

Overall a good, inexpensive, meal with friendly service in a pretty environment. I'd go again.
author: Raquel C.

description:
Was such a silly goose last time.

5 stars all the way. Staff are incredibly friendly, food is unbelievably well-priced.

We got the dungeness crab. Messiest but so, so, yummy.
author: Melanie W.

description:
Try anything that has the filet mignon in it.  No seriously - get your butt on the phone and order delivery!!  

I would have never tried this spot due to it's odd atmosphere. But I got so sick of eating at Rex Cafe - I stumbled in here one evening and have been a regular ever since!
author: Yelper A.

description:
Let's not lie, I'm slightly obsessed with this place.  I pretend I'm a vegetarian sometimes, and it's so easy to get great DAF-less (dead animal flesh) delicacies here.

The coolest thing about it is that a lot of the food has a "make it yourself" quality to it.  I appreciate the interaction factor, although I don't appreciate the way they sometimes look at me as if I'm doing it wrong.  If my crab wrap things fall apart, just go with it... (yeah, I eat crab, told you I PRETEND like I'm a vegetarian).  Their pho looks incredibly tempting, but I feel so badly cheating on Bodega Bistro that I haven't ordered it yet.  I have the hardest time ordering here because, honestly, everything looks so great.  The sugarcane crab things are a MUST for a shared appetizer, other than that I try to order something different each time.  I haven't been disappointed yet.  You can't beat a wine carafe for under 15 bucks!

Someone said this place was like a reasonably priced Slanted Door.  I like that - I love SD and this place, they definitely have similar styles of food.  Even if SD is more expensive and has sweet art on the walls, there's something homey about Aux Delices - in a really awkward way - kinda like me.
author: Caitlin D.

description: Best Vietnamese restaurant on Polk st. Been here numerous times and the food has always been consistently good. I highly recommend getting the garlic noodles and the claypot chicken.
author: Cam N.

description: That was pretty good, actually. I'd go back... I only had the ginger beef soup, so I'd need a heartier dish to make a more informed review....
author: Jodie B.

description:
I came here on a very special date with one of my very pretty best friends. I am not an expert when it comes to Vietnamese (french infusion too) food  (cough, cough, Cathy, don't scold my review!), but our experience was more than pleasant and the food was QUITE delicious.

We began with Chao Tom, grounded shrimp wrapped around sugar cane served with rice paper, pickled carrots, and cucumber. The waitress kindly showed us how to eat the appetizer, noting to take the sugarcane out and fill the rice paper up, then dip in the tasty sweet peanut sauce. Make sure you suck on the sugarcane after! (stop thinking dirty thoughts!).

Julie & I are big girls, so for our entrees, we didn't f*** around. We went straight for the BEEF n' BUTTER (2 staples in our diets). The Biftek Braise, charbroiled steak with butter and garlic served with veggies, was, BUTTERLICIOUS. And, it was cooked perfectly medium-rare just like we asked. 

Like seriously, lets take a moment to reflect on the buttery amazingness......Amen.

At one point, Julie and I considered pouring the buttery garlic sauce into our cups for a little drinky drink. This behavior might seem questionable, but you didn't taste the buttery goodness.

We also ordered the garlic egg noodles, which were tasty, but quite plain. I think some tofu would have added a nice touch, but I do appreciate simple dishes like such.  Can't wait to come back!
author: Laura D.

description:
Well, it's definitely cleaner than most Vietnamese restaurants--after all, this is Russian Hill.  Portion size was fine for what you pay, which gets huge marks from me.  Prices aren't bad--a few dollars more than I'm used to--but I've also had better for less.  

The staff are friendly, and the menu boasts numerous veggie options, including a gluten dish.  If you dine in, opt to sit in one of the booths; the seats are softer and cozier, complete with a throw pillow on each side.  

It should go without saying that parking is tough in this neighborhood.  If you're lucky enough to live nearby, you can always skip the parking hassle by taking advantage of their delivery ($20 min.) and enjoying their food in the comfort of your home.
author: Marsha Z.

description:
Take my word on this one...
Order the chicken pho.
It has changed my life, and it has the healing powers of something unwordly. Bad breakup? Eat the pho. Lost your job? Eat the pho. Progressive hangover? Eat the pho. I wouldn't be surprised if it cures cancer.
author: Kristen D.

description: I really enjoyed eating here.  We had the salmon in caramel sauce, garlic noodles, papaya salad, and Bo Luc Lac. They were all great.  For the price and the proximity to my home I would definitely eat here again!
author: Yana K.

description: YUMMY is all I have to say for this place. Not just great bang for your buck but the customer service is excellent. We have always had a great experience and great food when coming here. ENJOY
author: Maria L.

description:
This is one of my top three favorite restaurants in the city.  It's family run, I love Christine and her Mother Tina.  You can feel the love at this place.  Complex flavors, their proteins and vegetables are always cooked perfectly, and great presentation.  This is the place I take all out of town guests for a great meal.

Try the Imperial rolls, Crispy Chicken, Clay Pot Chicken, Salt and Pepper Prawn, garlic noodles
author: Seth A.

description:
This place is fantastic.  I have dined at a lot of restaurants in NYC, none satisfied me for the money like this place.  

Went with 3 friends, we got 4 different dishes at about $10 each and split all of them, each of them was so amazing we were practically licking the plates.  Also got a bottle of Geyser Peak Sauvignon Blanc for $24 and the total bill including tip and tax was $21/person.  For a dinner out with wine, that's a steal, I don't care what nationality the food is.
author: Spencer J.

description: Last minute dinner find and what a gem it was! The staff was amazing and very accommodating for a young family with a toddler. We tried their appetizer sampler of dumplings/rolls, beef pho, beef&broccoli in garlic/ginger sauce and beef/tofu in lemongrass sauce. We didn't leave a single drop of food! I've had hundreds of bowls of pho and this was definitely one to remember. Will definitely come back if we're back in town!
author: Sarah L.

description:
Absolutely delicious.  

We started with the tamarind spicy lemon grass soup - very flavorful with  lots of veggies & tofu.  I was hesitant at the word 'tamarind' but it was not overpowering and tasted great with the other flavors.

For mains we had veggie tofu (great flavor with lots of fresh veggies) and the crab silver noodles dish (amazing flavor).

The portion sizes were perfect and the customer service was attentive without being obtrusive.  My water glass never was empty as they were always nearby to refill.
author: Malorie E.

description:
I finally ate Vietnamese food! And it was Pho-reaking good!

Normally when anyone wants to take me out for food I haven't tried, I shrivel my nose and shrug my shoulders. I've been making it a point to try more stuff--this city is a great place for food & Aux Delices was a good spot to get acquainted with this particular style.

Vietnamese seems like half Thai & half Chinese to me...

We had the Claypot Caramel Chicken--super flavorful & piping hot when it came out of the kitchen. I Also tried the Noodle Salad with Chicken...it was good but had a few too many Pho noodles, I am guessing that I was a little burnt out on the noodles after my Pho Beef Soup.

They even serve a Vietnamese beer here, it's called "33" & reminded me of something similar to a St. Pauli Girl.

While the service here wasn't great, everything was very reasonably priced & has further spurred my interest in tasting more Vietnamese food around town!
author: matt m.

description:
Decided to try this place after seeing the reviews on yelp.  We ordered the imperial rolls, crab and shrimp glass noodles and the snapper with onions and mushrooms and green beans.  These are usually our go-to items everytime we eat vietnamese! 

To say we were disappointed was an UNDERSTATEMENT!!! The imperial rolls came out so quickly it made us question how long ago they were made, and the outside which is supposed to be crispy was soggy.  The crab and shrimp glass noodles were average at best and the least tasteful of all was the red snapper dish.  It had absolutely ZERO flavor! 

I would NOT recommend this restaurant ever!!!!!! Our dinner was $50 and I would have been much more satisfied with a Cup of Noodles!
author: Danielle H.

description:
The Dumplings aka the shrimp rolls are the best thing ever. Also when they can make six orders before they are closing, is a huge plus in my book. Plus their garlic noodles and Carmel chicken is delicious. Staff is super friendly and very patient. 

I would recommend this as a great date place or an excellent place to hit up after a long of night drinking at the Northstar. Yes they are that versatile!
author: Allan R.

description: Please!  $40 for frozen crab!!!  JUST BE HONEST WITH ME NEXT TIME!  If it's not fresh and you are charging me these prices, how about telling me so I won't be disappointed and feel obligated to write my honest opinion on here! JEEZ!!!
author: Tokyokid G.

description:
In an attempt to find a new vietnamese restaurant, I stumbled into this pleasant restaurant.  We started off with a soup, CANH CHUA, with Chicken, which was the first for me, it's usually w/ Shrimp but one of the choices were Chicken and tried that and was definitely worth the try!  It was tasty, a great starter.  We then had the CA KHO HAY CHIEN  (Catfish spicy clay pot style in a caramel sauce), which was sweet yet has it's spicy kick =)  another dish tried was the Marinated calamari sauteed in spicy basil curry sauce, yummy!   
     Decor was great, service was amazing, very friendly staff, it seems like a family owned establishment so you definitely feel they put their effort and love in their business... Overall.. i was very satisfied.  Its always great to try a nice quiet restaurant, that's ethnic too so i give it 5 stars w/ no reservations =)
author: Ryan M.

description:
I really wish I liked this place but for the 3rd time I have ordered their vegetable noodle soup to go and it had absolutely no noodles. Paying $10 bucks for that is pretty annoying. ( And no I am NOT ordering the wrong thing ha) I have had quite a few other things on their menu as well and am not that impressed. Like I said it is super convenient if you live in Russian Hill but other than convenience its not worth going.

On a side note if you eat the vegetable noodle soup there you magically get a ton of noodles.
author: Marian F.

description: It was fine, but with a four-star rating we expected it to be really good. We ordered the stuffed crepe and the noodle salad with imperial roll and pork. The crepe was super-fried and greasy and didn't have much filling. The bun was ok but generally  lacked flavor and we were disappointed by the imperial rolls which were too chewy and overcooked. I wouldn't refuse to eat here again but I wouldn't leave my house with this in mind as a destination. I'd  give the food we had two stars (meh-I've experienced better) but everyone there was very nice and the service was good, so I ain't mad.
author: m t.

description: Love this place!! The prices are reasonable, food is delicious, nice ambiance, and it's walking distance to my place - what's not to like!
author: Moxie C.

description: Delicious Vietnamese food! The catfish in the claypot is served in a sweet caramelized sauce that is just so good. I couldn't help but pour this sauce all over my brown rice. I also recommend the glass noodles with crab and shrimp. I will definitely come back!
author: Helen Y.

description:
Underperformer.   Food is a major bore.   Atmosphere is 1973, not in a good way.

Health report, not great.

http://sf.everyblock.com/restaurant-inspections/by-date/2010/5/14/3614608/
author: Trick C.

description: Home cooking good! My friend and I were apartment hunting and needed to eat ASAP. We found this place a cross of French and Vietnamese, and thus it was. My friend is French, and found the food to be just as good as it is in France. I love Vietnamese food, and found this to be an exceptional place. The area looked quiet and the restaurant was too, but the food was phenomenal. Kind of how I like it, my secret little yummy food place.
author: Homa S.

description:
I guess economic times are bad if you go to Aux Delices over Slanted Door.  I felt like I was in little Saigon in Westminster (So Cal).  

The tables were split, we had 1/2 meaters and 1/2 veggies - so we ordered family style.  We ordered the Viet Crepe, no good, but it was the best option we had that night.  Why 2 stars?  Good service.  But I wouldn't go back or recommend this to others who are vegetarian.
author: Bhumika K.

description:
SERVICE = "A-OK" as Yelp would say.

FOOD =  Honestly, I've had better pho and the medium portion is a bit small for the price.  I'm not surprised given that it's dining in SF.  The food is good, but there isn't really anything that sets it apart from others of its kind.. I like their bbq pork.

PAYMENT/PRICING =  A little more than I would want to pay especially since I get more for the money from other Vietnamese Restaurants.  

PARKING = Every man for himself--street parking.

*EXPERIENCE* = My fiance lives up the street and when I want pho, this is the closest place.. we've enjoyed dinners here.  The set-up is nice and we somehow usually end up sitting in the same spot every time.
author: Doreen M.

description: The food is great, the prices are right. Zen atmosphere, water infused with orange. I don't get why this place is always empty. The crepe appetizer is awesome. (note: it is not a crepe as you know it). The crispy chicken; I can't stop ordering it. They are skillfull with spices. The fish is great (note: the catfish has bones in it, and the salmon is divine). The caramel sauces are VERY good. Keep this place open and go often.
author: Andrew K.

description:
I have only had an app and a plate here with a side of rice so I haven't hit the whole menu but i had the imperial roll which was tasty and abundant, but the chicken and veggies were salty and had undercooked onions, minimal chicken, and the sauce was not all that. I actually didn't finish it. The friend i was with ordered a little side of a fried (something) rice (she said it was very bland) to offset her not finishing her entree either. So... in the end; Meh, I've experienced better. 

Too bad because i really like the location and decor.
author: Adam X.

description:
Just to preface, my 5-star restaurant reviews are not on par with SF Gate Michael Bauer's, Michelin, or Zagat reviews. My reviews are really about what makes a great restaurant to me on my taste buds, at my service, and for my disposable income. Aux Delices hit the perfect spot for those three criteria!

The casual and pleasantly decorated Vietnamese restaurant has these long booths which is conducive to group seating with plenty of table space for dishes and individual settings and swinging elbow room. Great for a group of 5-8 people.

The waitstaff are very sweet and attentive. When I mentioned my friend's reservation, turns out that she had not arrived, but two other of her friends that I did not know were outside waiting. And he gave me the option to seat first or hang out. Before the group conversation gets too boisterous later in the dinner, I decided to be social one-on-one and introduce myself instead. Bold, bold, bold step for me, but it was definitely worth it to ease the selection and sharing of dishes.

Aux delices's dishes are plentifully set up for sharing! We had 5 people in our party, and everyone had a substantial taste for each dish.  We ordered the spicy green papaya salad with squid, Vietnamese steamed dumplings, Vietnamese vegetarian crepe, caramel salmon, shrimp skewers, shaking beef, and another 2 dishes, which I can not remember. As long as you don't swallow three peppers in a row, the green papaya salad is not spicy. I love peppers!

The papaya salad, salmon, crepe, and steamed dumplings stood out, and I am craving them right now. The bill came out to be a very affordable $17 per person, including tip. All five of us were dumbfounded. Seriously? For a delicious meal sans complaints and happy faces? For that much food? Oh my gosh we're coming back!

For this part of the Russian Hill neighborhood, make sure you have aggressive San Francisco parking skills like me, or be ready to pay more in parking than a meal at Aux Delices. There is no valet.
author: Cathy H.

description: Great and fast service! Imperial rolls were excellent and the beef on skewers were delich  However, the Crispy chicken was worth ordering but a bit to crispy for my taste.
author: Ingrid O.

description:
4.5 stars for sure!!!  mmmmm definitely start with the fresh spring rolls - you get to make em yourself!  And they are nummers!  Team hangover got a variety of items including
*Imperial Roll Bun Noodle salad - bomb
*Tofu/Veggies - I believe also bomb
*Beef Satay - Holey delicious bomb
*Garlic Noodles - OMG bomb
*Marinated Beef Ribs - Crap this is f-ing tender and scrumptious bomb

Essentially everything was yummy and tender and tasty.   The price is really good for the ambiance and they even have (yes...bomb) desserts - I had mango sherbet/other members of team hangover had chocolate ice cream with those super sweet piroutte cookies.

**Hangover may have contributed to bombness of all food - but I am totally going back non H.O.and I know it will still be good good good!!
author: Melissa H.

description:
Given all the Thai / Vietnamese places there are in the city, one can very quickly get bored with all the selections, including consistency with the actual food.

I ordered delivery based on a recommendation from a friend and found the menu at first glance to be very attractive.  I ordered the following for me and the friend:
Spring Rolls
Asparagus Soup
Vietnamese Crepe - Starter
Beef w/ Ginger & Lemongrass

The Spring Rolls and peanut sauce were excellent
Asparagus Soup - not so good, basically egg drop soup with really large asparagus stalks
Vietnamese Crepe - this was completely undesirable, very oily, and just overall didn't settle well, it made us both ill
Beef w/ Ginger - this was decent, good lemongrass & ginger flavors, but the meat was tough and overall very greasy

Overall I can't say the meal was worth the money, $40 for the dishes...
To boot, on the delivery slip, everything that we were charged for was $0.50 over the published price...  What is it with SF, everywhere you go someone is trying to screw customers out of money, not the first place I have seen this.

On top of being overcharged for the food, on the credit slip (so conveniently) next to the 'Tip' line they had written in '10% Mandatory' - isn't this at the discretion of the patron?

I wouldn't recommend this place to anyone based on our experience.
author: Sam M.

description:
Almost fine dining. Shatangi appreciates the lovely decor and formal service of this moderatly priced upperesque-scale French-Vietnamese joint. Dishes are well prepared and presented.

Shatangi told you
author: Njon W.

description:
This review is for their delivery. I've never actually set foot in Aux Delices. 

Their takeout menu has a lot of great stuff on it and definitely seemed like a better option than some of the other fast-foodish Thai options in my neighborhood. I ordered a chicken, mushroom and noodle soup, green papaya salad and some noodles with shrimp and the total came out to $30. Everything was absolutely delicious and perfectly seasoned. They definitely used high quality ingredients. Plus the portions were very generous. I had more than enough to take to work for 2-3 lunches, and the food held up very well for leftovers. 

Another bonus - they were extremely quick. Although the guy on the phone told me 40-45 minutes, the food arrived in about 20.
author: Lindsey S.

description:
Last night I dined with a friend of mine who lives a block away from Aux Delices and when we walked in, I immediately got the stink-eye.  The hostess wouldn't acknowledge me and insisted that we needed a table for three.

Apparently, they were surprised that my friend wasn't with her long-term boyfriend and they were suspicious of my motives.  WE'RE NOT HAVING AN AFFAIR!!!  (And if we were, it would be pretty foolish to sneak around at the local Vietnamese restaurant that is one block away from her house!)

In any case, we had a lovely meal and both greatly enjoyed the basil chicken.
author: Marcus C.

description:
Delivery:
Delicious food, delivered slowly. 
I order an hour (or more) before I expect to need it, and then all is well.


Eat in:
Delicious food, reasonable service and decor.
author: Max R.

description:
I'm a HUGE fan of Slanted Door (see earlier review), but its not always a meal I'm willing to pay for. Now I've found a cheaper alternative. Aux Delices has great Vietnamese-French food that can stand up to the amazing food at Slanted Door... except Aux Delices is a fraction of the price. The average entree was only $10.  A dinner for 7 people only cost $150. And we had leftovers. I especially loved the Caramel Chicken in a Clay Pot. 

I highly recommend this place if you're looking for Slanted Door-type  food for a more reasonable price. But watch out, parking is hard on a Friday/Saturday night.
author: eileen b.

description:
Can you say "Yummerz!!"?!?!? So I've been a bit homesick and I was craving some Vietnamese food. First and foremost, lemme tell you that I am picky as hell when it comes to Vietnamese food since my Mom always made me the authentic stuff. So it's Wednesday night and my groups of foodies and friends (now known as Wednesday night E.A.T.S) get together, this time being MY turn to pick the restaurant. So I pick Aux Delices over on Polk.

The restaurant is absolutely darling, comfortable booths and plenty of seating. We made a reservation for 6 and were easily accomodated.

For appetizers, we started with Cha Gio (Imperial Rolls). Chao Tom (Shrimp on Sugar Cane) and Banh Cuon (Steamed flat dumplings). The Imperial Rolls were fried to perfection, crispy but not overly oily. The Shrimp on Sugar Cane came with rice paper to assemble your own rolls, which was fun and everyone enjoyed! The Banh Cuon, nice and traditional, simple and delicious.

With dinner we ordered a bottle of Gruner Veltliner, perfect clean, crisp with a bright acidity that paired well with most our dishes. For dinner, we enjoyed BBQ Pork Fried Rice, Caramelized Clay Pot Catfish, Sauteed Garlic Green Beans, and Garlic Noodles....the garlic noodles were so good, we had to get another order! Yummerz! Everything is done to perfection, the Clay Pot Catfish came out hot and bubbling and the sauce was perfect drizzled over the garlic noodles. 

For dessert, we all shared an order of fried bananas and coconut ice cream! Traditional, simple and utterly delicious! I should've gotten an extra scoop of coconut ice cream with it! :)

Overall, the staff was friendly and attentive, Mr. Nguyen the owner himself took our order and was very nice along with all the waitstaff! Will definitely be bringing back the buddies next time I've got a craving for Vietnamese food! 

5 Yummerz stars from me!!! YAY!
author: Ann T.

description:
As a  nurse at San Francisco General, I have often eaten at Aux Delices on Potrero Avenue.  Yesterday, I had lunch with three
girlfriends at the Post Street location.  What a lovely occasion it was!!
The setting was much more festive than I anticipated - very serene, with a buddha at the entrance, and brillant fresh flowers everywhere, in honor of the owner's 50th birthday.  I had a lychee sakitini to start the meal - very tasty  - and shared a sampler platter which was a 
meal in itself - spring rolls, imperial rolls, dumplings.  My friend's
crab asparagus soup was a wonderful flavor combination which I'll
order myself next time.
     I ordered my usual chicken sauteed with ginger and lemongrass,
asking for extra ginger ( and garlic as well...) absolutely  a dish fit
for the gods, served with rice to absorb every bit of the sauce.  Ummmmmm!!  Since I'd heard so much about the Bo Luc Lac 
( shaken filet mignon with garlic ), we tried that as well.  It was 
tender, every morsel a bite to savor.  
   We were too full for dessert but sat there long after everyone else
had gone, enjoying the day and the setting and the aftermath of a 
wonderful meal.
   I highly recommend this lovely restaurant!
author: Carmen H.

description:
Love the BBQ pork!!!  Solid vietnamese food.

Only get takeout - the atmosphere is horrible in the restaurant.  You kind of feel like your eating in a library and anything and everything you say can clearly be heard by the waitstaff and other diners.
author: Ali G.

description: Delish! I always *think* I need to head down to the tenderloin to get good/authentic vietnamese food and didnt even think of this place which is right in my front yard! The service was excellent and the food was even better. My favorite was the crispy chicken, fried rice (and I usually dont like fried rice because it's dry but this was so mushy and delicious) and garlic noodles (obvi and always). I'll be back! :)
author: Lindsay D.

description:
